loans.name: Norberta

texts.en: Norberta is a 36 year old married woman. Her business is a sari-sari (variety) store; she sells goods to her neighbors and people in her town. She has three children she takes care of very lovingly. As a member of CEVI, she hopes that the MFI will continue to grow and help the poor. Norberta applied for a loan of PHP 12,000. She will use this loan to buy stocks for her store so that she can be of service to people in her town.

loans.use: financing

loans.name: Merry Chill

texts.en:
Merry Chill C. lives in the village of Estaka. She is 32 years old, married, has four school-aged children and makes a living providing motor cab services to people who live in her area. She has been in this business for more than one year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2006, Merry Chill joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid eight previous loans from PMPC, and has requested a new loan of 11,000 PHP to repair her vehicle. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to pay for the education of her children. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair her cab

loans.name: Bibi Sharefa Group

texts.en: Bibi Sharefa is the group leader of Bibi Sharefa group. There are three members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan to progress their business and make it larger. So they are requesting a group of loan 30000 Afghani. Bibi Sharefa wants to take a loan for the business of bead working. Leela wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Hanifa wants to take a loan for the business of carpet weaving. So they thank AFS and Kiva lenders who can support all entrepreneurs around the world.

loans.use: To buy bead working materials

loans.name: Tutafika Group

texts.en:
Makame K. is 32 years old, married, and has four children who ages 13, 9, 3 and 9 months. He is also raising his neice, who is 19. Since 2005, Makame has made a living selling fish. He works daily from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of around $153.

This will be Makame’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his first loan to buy more fish to sell. He paid it back successfully, and plans to use this new loan to buy more fish.
	
Makame will share this loan with his group, Tutafika, which has 16 members. Seven of them sell fish, like Makame. Several others have small food stands, and one sells clothing. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. In the photo, Makame  is the first person on the right in the back row.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to his customers

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith A. is a 33-year-old widow with three children, two girls and one boy. She lives in the Nyamasaria neighborhood of Kisumu, Kenya, where she went into business as a tailor in 2000. She then opened up a small grocery store, and continues to plow her profits into expanding it. She gets her groceries and tailoring supplies in the towns of Kisumu and Busia. She picks up new groceries three times a week and tailoring materials once a week. Judith has applied for a loan to expand her grocery store by buying more items to sell to her customers. In the future, she also plans to buy a motorcycle and begin a small transportation business.

loans.use: To buy materials for a grocery store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Din Mohammad

texts.en:
Din M. is the son of E. M.. He lives in the 16th district of Kabul Afghanistan. He is 50 years old and is married with seven children. He has been a farmer since he was a child. He works hard on his land in order to have lots of clients and sell much of his fresh vegetables. He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani to purchase all his necessary materials. 
He is glad and would like to mention that Kiva is the best process.

loans.use: To buy materials needed for farming

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice O. is married and has two children, one girl and one  boy. She first heard of Kiva from K-MET Community Health Workers during one of their mobilization and community service meetings. She immediately became interested and decided to become a member. 

Beatrice makes a living selling second-hand clothes in Nyalenda, Kisumu, Kenya. She started this business in 2000 and has never regretted the day she decided to do more than be a housewife. Beatrice has applied for a loan to restock and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell to her customers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mahdi

texts.en: Mahdi is 26 years old, married and has two young children. For more than two years, he has made a living selling vegetables. Mahdi has applied for a $1,000 loan to buy additionA. merchandise to satisfy customer demand, which is very heavy because he is so well known in his community.

loans.use: To buy additional vegetables to sell to his customers

loans.name: Conjester

texts.en: Conjester N. is a 33 year old woman and the sole owner of a tailoring business. She started this business in 2008 as a self-employment project. She says it has paid off and she buys her tailoring stock twice a month. Initially, she was in the grocery business. Conjester says the income from the grocery business helped her get trained as a tailor. Now she has her eyes set on buying more sewing machines and resurrecting her old grocery business.  Her future dream is to buy a parcel of land with the profits from her businesses.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials and equipment

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Puriza

texts.en:
Motorcycle transport is the primary source of income of Puriza and her husband Crispin in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. Aside from the transport business, Crispin is also engaged in farming, while Puriza sometimes sells bamboo shoots in their village to earn extra income. 

For the continuous development of their transport business, Puriza is again requesting a loan amounting to PHP7,000 from lenders. She hopes that her loan will again be approved to enable her retail business to grow and earn more profit. 

Puriza & Crispin's three elder children have already graduated from college while the youngest is presently enrolled in college getting a Bachelor of Science in Information Technology. The couple hope that their youngest child will also receive a college degree.

loans.use: To buy some materials for their transport business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Salaman

texts.en: Salaman is the son of G. M.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives in a family of five members. He wants to get married. Salaman needs money for wedding expenses. Since he spent more money, he requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani. He would like to say that the loan process is the best because it can support those who really need money.

loans.use: For wedding expenses

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice C. is a resident of Manyatta, a slum area in Kisumu, Kenya. She is also a practicing community health worker and runs a business of grocery selling. She started this business in 2002 because she wanted to supplement her husband’s income. Beatrice says it has made it easier for them to take care of their four children. Her future plans is to make sure her business expands, her children get the best of education and that her family rests on a stable life economically. Beatrice would like a loan of $275.

loans.use: To buy more grocery stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Frankielou

texts.en:
Frankielou M. is from the city of Maningcol Ozamiz City. He is 25 years old. Frankielou is married. To make a living, Frankielou owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Frankielou has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Frankielou joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Frankielou is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Frankielou from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Edith Fedha

texts.en:
Edith M. is 48 years old, married to Nebart and blessed with four children. Her clothing business is located in Chepkoilel Campus in Eldoret Town.

Edith was introduced to KADET by an existing member. With the loan she hopes to receive she intends to add clothing stock which includes jackets, children clothes and t-shirts. Her dream is to be a wholesaler and be able to educate her children.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower their clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more clothing stock.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is 33 years old and married to Miriam, who is  27. They are blessed with two beautiful daughters. He was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, through an existing client. He is applying for his first loan with KADET.

He does carpentry work for learning institutions and individuals. He intends to increase his stock of wood and fabric materials for furniture making. With the extra profit he gets, he is planning to purchase a piece of land and build a house for his family.

His hopes and dreams are to expand his primary business of carpentry and open another workshop. He describes himself as a confident, hardworking man who makes quality products.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase stock of wood and fabric materials for furniture making

loans.name: Christopher Kungu

texts.en:
Christopher is 26 years old and married with two children. He sells natural medicines from Dynapharm to his clients. He has been in the business for three years and has been making a monthly profit of about 18,000 Kenyan shillings. He plans to use the loan to buy more Dynapharm products to sell to his customers. He was introduced to KADET by a friend. He hopes to have his own Dynapharm products stall and buy a body examining machine.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of microentrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To buy more natural medicine (Dynapharm) products to sell to customers

loans.name: Alice Muthoni

texts.en:
Alice Muthoni is 41 years old and married with three children. She has dairy cows which help her to supply milk to her customers in the Thamanda area. She has been running this business for three years and now makes monthly profit of approximately 25,000 Kenyan shillings. Alice wants to buy two more dairy cows in order to meet increased demand. She has never borrowed from another MFI. One day, she hopes to own a big dairy farm to supply milk to other areas.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: Buying two more dairy cows to produce milk to sell

loans.name: Rossel

texts.en: Rossel is 28 years old, married and has one child; her dream is to expand her business, a general store, where she gets her income to support her family. She also dreams that her seven-year-old child will be able to obtain a quality education, finish college and find a decent job. Rossel has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and she is grateful because her loans were really helpful, not just to her business but also to her family. Now she is requesting a loan of Php 10,000. This loan will be used to purchase goods for the store and hopefully, little by little, to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her general store

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence is 27 years old and a single man. He is applying for his fourth loan with KADET. He plans to buy a motorcycle to use to transport produce and other goods  to market, to expand business and open a milk bar. This will enable him to increase customers and sources of income.  He came to know about KADET through market outreach in Juja town.

With the extra profit he earns he intends to expand his business and open a dairy outlet.  His future hope is to open a transport business.

Lawrence can be described as a very hardworking man, he says "I am determined and never give up on what I am pursuing despite the challenges. My motto is: never give up, keep moving forward."

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use to transport goods to market

loans.name: Del Agha

texts.en: This is Del Agha, the son of A. Q.. He lives in Bagrami, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 45 and married with five children. He is a hard working man. He has a shop in which he sells rice and flour. He wants to take an individual loan of 40000 Afghani to buy more materials for his shop and add to the number of his clients. He is glad that through the loan process he can progress and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for his shop

loans.name: Rosalima

texts.en:
Rosalima is 35 years old, married, and has two children. The elder is school-aged and the other one is infant-aged.  To make a living, Rosalima owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising chickens for sale. Rosalima is just starting this business.

In 2007, Rosalima joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosalima is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase construction materials for house repair. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosalima from PMPC.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for house repair

loans.name: Benta

texts.en:
Benta A. is a 31 year old married woman and a mother of two children, a girl and a boy. She considers herself a family person. She says this is defined by her zeal to keep everyone in the family on their toes to know the importance of determination in life.

Benta runs a charcoal business which she started in the year 2004. Benta would like a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings, which she says will go to restocking of her charcoal business in time for the Christmas holidays – peak time sales, as she puts it.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for resale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary Jelagat

texts.en:
Mary is 36 years old and married to Ernest Koech. Together they have two boys and two girls: Wyclife, Festus, Judith, and Lorna. The oldest is aged 18, and the youngest is 10.

Mary was introduced to KADET by a friend. She has never borrowed from another MFI. She has taken a loan from KADET before worth 45,000 Kenyan shillings in order to boost her dairy farming and cereal business. She sells the cereals (maize and beans) to the nearby Tambach High School and Tambach Teachers College. The milk she gets from her dairy cows she sells to her neighbors. Mary gets additional income from vegetables which she grows on her farm.

With this loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings, Mary plans to purchase an additional dairy cow, plant beans and buy more maize. If this loan helps increase her profits, she plans to use the extra money to open a kiosk in her village.

Mary says she is hard working and independent. She hopes to become self sustainable. Her biggest dream is giving the best education to her children.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase an additional dairy cow and farm inputs.

loans.name: Selina Jeruto

texts.en:
Selina is 36 years old, married to a farmer named Isaac, and blessed with four children. She runs a clothing business located in Eldoret Town.

With this loan from KADET, Selina intends to buy more clothing for her clothing sales business. This includes dresses and trousers for children and adults. She was introduced to KADET by a friend.

Her dreams are to improve her clothing business, buy a vehicle, and one day to have the ability build her own house.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Ann Njeri

texts.en:
Ann Njeri is 32 years old and married with two children. She owns dairy cows which help her supply milk to people in a country where dairy products are very popular.  She has been in the business for eight years.

Ann wants to use the loan to buy an extra cow in order to increase her milk supply. She was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a member.  She hopes to one day own a big dairy farm that will help her maximize her profits.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy an extra cow to increase milk supply.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 40 yrs old, married to Cecilia, and the father of six children. He is applying for his first loan with KADET.  With this loan Joseph intends to buy cooking ingredients for his cafe, such as wheat flour and cooking oil.

Joseph came to know about KADET through World Vision Kenya and KADET farmers' field day.  His hopes and dreams are to improve living standards for his family and be able to provide a good education for his children.

Joseph has also taken in an orphan and is struggling to put him through school. His greatest desire is to assist such members in the community only that he is limited in resources. He hopes to use some of his business profits to provide food and education for orphans in his community.

Joseph can be described as very committed to leadership, honesty, and hard work.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add stock to sell such as wheat flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 59 years old and married to Josephine who is 51 years old. They are blessed with four sons and two daughters.  He runs a general shop and wants to increase his stock by buying flour, rice, and other household items.

He came to know about Kadet through World Vision Kenya and KADET farmers' field day. This will be his first loan with KADET.  Peter wants to open a wholesale store some day, and hopes to expand his business and train his children to run other stores.

He describes himself as an honest business man, patient and very good at record keeping.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy stock for a general store such as flour, rice and household items.

loans.name: Douglas Shilechilli

texts.en:
Douglas is married and blessed with two children. His business is located at the roadblock in Soy. He was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by a group member. 

Douglas is taking a loan from KADET so that he can buy spare parts for his motorcycle, which is a taxi. His plan is to grow the business and to be able to educate his children.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Nahason Lusesi

texts.en: Nahason is 26 years old and married. His has motorcycle taxi business located in Eldoret. With this loan from KADET, Nahason will buy new tires for his motorcycle taxi. He was introduced to KADET by a friend. Nahason's future plans are to grow his business and he hopes to be able to educate his children. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy tires for his motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 21 years old.  He wants a loan to add stock to his general store. He hopes to attract more customers, especially those from outside his neighborhood.  In addition to his retail shop, Peter has a side business selling broiler chickens.

This will be Peter's first loan from KADET. He was introduced to KADET through an existing client.

Peter's hopes and dream are to improve his living standards and to be able to purchase his own motorcycle to transport goods to clients at market.  Peter can be described as a hardworking man who believes in his ability to succeed.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more stock for a small general store.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is 36 years old, married and blessed with four children. His business is located at Mautuma (Makutano) in Eldoret.

He was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by a friend.

With the loan he is intending to receive from KADET, he will buy maize to sell to customers. In the future he hopes to start a transportation business to bring maize to places that are far away. With his profits, he hopes to be able to continue educating his children.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy maize to sell to customers

loans.name: Abdul Moaner

texts.en: Abdul Moaner is the son of R. B.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives in a family of seven members. He wants to take a loan for his family problems. He works in the government.  He requested an individual loan of 30000 Afghani. He would like to say that the loan process is the best because it can support those who really need money and want to have a good future.

loans.use: For completing his requirements

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 30 years old and married with three children. She sells cereals to her customers in the Karinde shopping center. She has been in the business for the past nine years with a monthly profit of about 30000 Kenyan shillings. She wants to use the loan to buy more cereals to meet the demand of her customers and to increase her profits.  

She has never borrowed from another MFI before and was among the founders of her group in KADET.  She hopes to operate a large-scale grocery and cereals shop one day so as to have enough supplies for the area.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Restock her cereals shop (e.g. maize)

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith O. is a 24 year old lady, married, and the mother of one child, a boy.  Before she started her current produce business, Judith says she preferred to be a housewife. That is until she realized she had a lot of demands to satisfy and that her husband could not shoulder them alone.

Judith wants a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings and intends to buy fruit and vegetables for resale.

She has not regretted her choice to open a business.  Her dream is to buy a parcel of land and prove wrong the old adage in her community that says, "Women cannot buy land."  She says, “Just watch and see.  I will prove these men wrong.”

loans.use: To buy produce for resale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Peruce Mandela

texts.en:
Peruce O. is 33 years-old and married with two children. She is in the food production business selling food to her customers in the Umoja estate. She has been in the business for a period of six years and earns a profit of approximately 8000 kenyan shillings a month.  
Mp>
Peruce plans to use the loan to open a cafeteria and a bakery. She has never borrowed from another MFI before and was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by the chairman of her group. Peruce aspires to open a hotel (a cafe) and a restaurant in the future.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To open a cafeteria and a bakery.

loans.name: Levita Gina

texts.en:
Levita Gina is 38 years-old and happily married to Elmer. They are blessed with four children: Emmanuel, 9; Giboy, 8; Eraño, 4 and Ediboy, 2. They are living in the peaceful village of Jurisdiction, Amulung, Cagayan.

Levita and her husband decided to invest into a junk shop business after they got married. They collect and buy scrap materials like used bottles, old newspapers, boxes, plastic bottles and other recyclable materials that they can resell at higher prices. In order to expand their business, she would like to request a loan amount of PHP 15,000 from KIVA lenders. This amount will really help her to improve her business. Despite the hardship they are encountering in their business, Levita said that with their deep faith in God, they can fight life's challenges.

loans.use: Additonal capital.

loans.name: Sarah Jepkorir

texts.en:
Sarah is 40 years old, married to John and blessed with five children. Her retail business is located at the Junction in Eldoret. She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend. With the loan Sarah plans to add stock to her business, including sugar, plastic, jericans, rice and cooking fat. In the future she aspires to grow her business and provide financial support for her children.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase additional retail stock.

loans.name: Ismael Mohammed

texts.en:
Ismael is 36 years-old and is married. His electronic business is located at Likuyani market in Likuyani area, Eldoret. He was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a business partner. With the loan Ismael intends to add electronic products to his shop such as cables. His future dreams is to open a big electronic shop and to be able to manage his family well.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy electronic goods.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena, 45 years of age, is married to Mr. Venchito I. who works as a van driver. The couple is blessed with four children: Bernie Berlin, 24; his brother Christian, 22, a bank accountant; Cherry Pie, 19, a second year college student, and Vincent, 16. They are happily residing in Sta. Cruz, Alicia which is a rural area.

Elena sells dry good merchandise such as bags, clothing and shoes. Her daily net income is Php 250 which is very useful to meet their daily needs especially with regards to food. Elena sometimes buys some of her products from her sister then sells it at a higher price to gain profit. She plans to continue her business to support her family especially the education of their children. She would like to use the loan of Php 8,000 from Kiva partner ASKI in order to buy more merchandise. Elena said that patience is her key to success.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela A. is from the village of Lower Dicayas. She is 51 years old. Carmela is married and has 3 children. Two of her children are adults and the youngest is school-aged.  To make a living, Carmela raises and sells pigs. Carmela has been engaged in her business for over 5 years with an approximate average monthly earnings of 3,000 PHP from these activities.

In 2008, Carmela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Carmela is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase grocery stocks for her sari-sari store business.Carmela manages pig raising and a sari-sari store at home for an income. This will be Carmela's 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions and support her children education. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase grocery stocks for the  business

loans.name: Kakh-E-Qadem Group

texts.en:
This is Kakh-e-Qadem Group and Khanam Gul is the group leader. This group is made up of three female members and each of them would like to expand their business and bring some new changes to it.

Khanam Gul would like to take a loan for her husband’s fruit shop. They both share the work of the business: Khanam Gul cleans and packages the fruit and the husband sells it in the shop.

Shuker Gul wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy a new sewing machine in order to sew good-quality clothes and have lots of new clients.

Nazifa wants to take a loan for her quilt-making business to purchase essential materials for it.

Together, they have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani. They all admire the process of Kiva loans.

loans.use: To use as business capital for her husband's shop

loans.name: Joseph Mwangi

texts.en:
Joseph Mwangi is a 51-year-old farmer. He is married and has three children. His primary business is to supply milk to his customers in Ngecha, Kikuyu. On the side, he also has a vegetable farm from which he supplies vegetables to Ngecha. He has been supplying milk for about seven years. He has been able to collect a monthly profit of about 20000 Kenyan shillings. 

Joseph wants to buy an extra cow to increase his milk supply.  He is the founder of his borrower group and has not borrowed from any other sources before. In the future, he hopes to own a big dairy farm with over ten cows, each producing about 30 litres of milk per day.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy an extra dairy cow to supply milk to community

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 47 yrs old and married to Elena. They are blessed with four children, two sons and two daughters. He was introduced to Kadet through an existing client. He is applying for his second loan.

Joseph owns and operates a butcher shop. He will use his loan to expand his business and diversify the food he sells to ultimately increase his income. In the future, he intends to buy a car and a motorbike and open a green-grocery business with the extra profit he earns.

He dreams about purchasing a piece of land and and developing it into rental houses. He describes himself as a focused man and a hardworking business man.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase additional food to sell in his butcher shop

loans.name: Edlie

texts.en:
Edlie L. sells  “halo-halo,” a snack that contains different fruits, such as banana, jack fruit, cassava, and coconut and other flavorings, such as ice and milk. This has been her business for twenty-four years and it has helped her family to survive. She generates an income of Php 6,000 from her business every month. 

She dreams about expanding her business by acquiring additional capital of Php 5,000. She plans to buy more supplies for her business, such as glasses, spoons, containers and other materials that will be very helpful to her business. She anticipates for a higher income with help from ASKI.

Edlie is a forty-five-year-old woman. Her family lives in the village of Magsaysay in Naguilian, Isabela. Harley, her loving husband, is a well-known carpenter in their village. They still send their four children in school, which is the reason why the couple works hard. They hope to support all their children's educational needs so they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her halo-halo business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Wainaina

texts.en:
Wainaina is 58 yrs old and is married to Tabitha. They are blessed with three children. He was introduced to Kadet through an existing client. He is applying for his 2nd loan from Kadet. With this loan, Wainaina is planning to increase his stock of clothes and diversify his business by stocking other household items. Wainaina targets youth because they have a taste for new clothes.

He intends to use extra profits to expand his business, and save part of his profits for an emergency or stability fund. His future hope and dream is to open a wholesale store. He describes himself as a hardworking man; prayerful, faithful and honest.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase stock of clothing for his store and to diversify his goods by selling other household items

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a 26-year-old single gentleman. He was introduced to Kadet by an existing client. He is applying for his first loan from Kadet. With this loan, David is planning to increase his stock and sell goods, such as potatoes and peas, in bulk. He intend to reinvest his profits in his business.

His future hopes and dreams are to build a good house and eventually marry and support a family.

David was affected by the post-election violence that occurred in Kenya in 2007. He lost his first business, which was worth $7000 USD and was an internally displaced person for two months. But he has forgotten the past and decided to move on with life. He moved to Thika (his current hometown) and started a business all over again.

He describes himself as a very confident man; hardworking, positive and very decisive.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock and sell in bulk (potatoes, peas, etc)

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 29 years old. She was introduced to Kadet by an existing client. She is applying for her first loan from Kadet. She is planning to increase the stock of her grocery business, and buy vegetables, such as tomatoes, green kale, and onions, to give her clients a better selection and higher quality products.

With the extra profits that she earns, she intends to expand her business and stock fresh milk, which is in demand in her locality. Her dream is to open a supermarket some day.

Ruth is a focused lady. She felt insecure when her initial stock was stolen several times due to the location and poor structure in which she operated. She worked hard and was able to afford a more durable business store that offers her better security. She describes herself as a lady who never gives up. She is very hardworking and very courteous to her clients. She values people.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase stock for her grocery kiosk (tomatoes, onions, kale, cabbage)

loans.name: Hadela Rahoof Group

texts.en:
This is Hadela Rahoof Group and Hadela is the group leader. They each would like to expand their business and buy essential materials.

There are three members in this group:

Hadela wants to take a loan for her poultry business.

Sharifa wants to take a loan for her tailoring business to buy essential materials.

M. Rahoof wants to receive a loan for his metal shop.

They are all happy from this process and they have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani.

loans.use: To expand her poultry business

loans.name: Jerida

texts.en:
Jerida is a 36 year-old married mother of six children who runs a grocery store in the Mathare slums of Nairobi. She has run this business for ten years and hopes to expand the business to earn a better income so she can move away from the slums. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy more Irish potatoes and tomatoes, and a tomato box. She describes herself as full of potential and ready to achieve. 

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy more Irish potatoes, tomatoes, and a tomato box.

loans.name: Mungai

texts.en:
Mungai is 39 yrs old and is married to Loise, who is 34 yrs old. They are blessed with two sons and two daughters. He was introduced to Kadet by an existing member of Kadet. He is applying for his 2nd loan.

Mungai does horticultural farming and sells horticultural products to Kenya Horticultural Exporters. He also supplies green kale to the local community. He intends to expand his farm with the extra profit that earns from this loan. His future dream is to own a big farming corporation.

He describes himself as a good Christian, a hardworking man, a farmer, and a successful businessman.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies, such as seedling, to sell to Kenya Horticultural Exporters

loans.name: Gualberta

texts.en:
Gualberta A. is from the town of Poblacion1 in Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Gualberta is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gualberta sells fish. Gualberta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Gualberta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gualberta has successfully repaid a previous loan 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Gualberta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her business. This will be Gualberta's sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her business

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate is a 23-year-old mother of one child who operates a hotel in Thogoto in Nairobi. She has been in this business for one year and hopes to expand it and open multiple outlets in major towns in Kenya. She is requesting a first loan of Kes. 10,000 to renovate the hotel and buy supplies, such as sugar. Her life has changed since joining Faulu because she has learned how to save for her future. She saves Kes. 100 every day. She describes herself as industrious.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To renovate her hotel and buy cereals and sugar.

loans.name: Eladio

texts.en:
Eladio E. is from the village of P-1 Kinangay Sur in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 55 years old. Eladio is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Eladio plants, harvest, and sells rice. Eladio has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Eladio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eladio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from GDMPC. Eladio is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be Eladio's second loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is 54 years old and already a widow.  She was left with seven children, six of whom are already married. Her youngest child, her son Christopher, is still single. Four member of her family lives together at Sta.Cruz, Alicia, Isabela, a rural and plain area. Their house is along the national highway.

Dolores has been managing a retail store for almost six years and her weekly net income is Php 800.00 (~ $17 USD). She wants a Php 15,000 (~$325 USD) loan from Kiva to buy grocery items to sell, and to buy hog feed for her hog-raising business. She works continuously to improve her business and to increase her daily income so that she can meet her family's basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items and hog feed

loans.name: Steven Ndungu

texts.en:
Steven is 53 years old and married. He has three children. Steven is a photograher and most of his clients call him to take photos of weddings and other occasions. He has been in the business for about 20 years. He earns a profit of approximately 20000 Kenyan shillings (~$270 USD) a month.

He is the founder of his borrower group. He has never borrowed from an MFI and intends to use the loan to buy a video camera to meet his clients' demands. He hopes to own a big photo studio some day that will help him produce the photos and reduce his costs.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a video camera for his photography business

loans.name: Mercaya

texts.en:
Mercaya L. is from the city of Gango Ozamiz. She is 25 years old. Mercaya is married and has one young child. To make a living, Mercaya sells scrap metal and other used products in the local community. Mercaya has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Mercaya joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercaya has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from GDMPC. Mercaya is requesting a new loan of 6,500 PHP that she will use to expand her business. This will be Mercaya's fifth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
Houssein is a 30 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Houssein has been working as a car mechanic since 2000. He owns a garage, repairs cars, and sells cars spare parts. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase tools and spare parts for his garage. This is his second loan and he has always repaid on time. His previous loan helped him to improve his garage by buying new tools.

When Houssein first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties. He decided to start this business because he had been employed in a garage, but decided that he'd rather work independently. In the future, he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and spare parts for his garage.

loans.name: Isaak Machani

texts.en:
Isaak is 33 years old and married. He has two children. He owns a small bakery in Dagoretti where he prepares different kinds of bread and cakes. He has been in this business for five months and earns about 20000 Kenyan shillings (~ $270 USD) per month in profits.

He wants to use his loan to buy more raw materials for his bakery so he can increase his production. He has not borrowed from any financial institutions before and hopes to have a bigger bakery to produce more bread.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for his bakery

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth O. sells charcoal. She started her business in 2004 when she was just 19 years old. By then, she was already a wife and a mother. Her business is located in Manyatta, Kisumu, Kenya. It is doing well and she wants to expand it, because it’s a lucrative venture for a family income. 

She is currently a mother of four and her future plan is to go into rental business. Her charcoal business is her first step. She says the rental houses will guarantee school fees for her children. Elizabeth wants a loan of KShs. 10,000 that she will use to purchase more stock.

loans.use: To stock more charcoal

loans.name: Benard

texts.en: Benard is the 29-year-old married father of two children who runs a laundry service in the Mathare slums of Nairobi. He has been in this business for ten years and hopes to expand into a very big standardized laundry shop. Benard is requesting a loan of Kes 35,000 to buy a washing machine. He hopes to create a better life by expanding his business through loans from Faulu. He says that, through Faulu, he has also developed the skill of saving. He describes himself as optimistic and hardworking. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy a washing machine

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet F. is 41 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a retail clothing business. While it is not Janet's only means of generating income, her clothing business is her main source of income. Janet has had her business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month. In 2009, Janet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the first Janet has taken out from HSPFI. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital.

location.town: Santa Felomena, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Michael Thuo

texts.en:
Michael is 57 years old, married to Rose, and they have five daughters and one son, all adults. He was introduced to Kiva Partner, KADET, through an existing KADET client and has been a shopkeeper for four years.

Michael is applying for his 3rd loan with KADET. He is intending to purchase more stock and expand his retail shop business.

With the extra profit generated from his business, Michael is planning to install electricity in his shop and purchase a deep-freezer. His hopes and dreams are to have a big business which can serve as both wholesale and retail. He describes himself as a hardworking man and very focused.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more stock and expand his business

Roselyn owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Roselyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. loans.name: Oroyinyin

texts.en: Oroyinyin is 45 years old and married with four children.  He sells VCDs in retail to his customers. He wants a loan of N170,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 41 years old and is married to Edivencio, who works in a lumber company. They have been married for 23 years and they are blessed with two children: Jovelyn - 23 years old, a cashier, and John Lerry - 17 years old. They live in Sta. Cruz, Alicia, Isabela.

Marilyn has managed a retail store in their village for almost seventeen years and she can earn a weekly net income of PHP 1,000. She wishes to apply for a loan of PHP 11,000 from Kiva lenders that she can use for the improvement of her business.

Aside from selling basic commodities, Marilyn also sells cooked food in their village in order to have an additional income with which to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Beth

texts.en: Beth is a 50 year-old widow with five children. She has run a food kiosk in the Mathare slums of Nairobi for 18 years and previously had a grocery store. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more food and a mkokoteni (hand cart). She says that she has been able to educate her children because loans from Faulu have allowed her to expand her business. She hopes to one day buy land and a pickup truck for the business and make a better life for her family away from the slums. She describes herself as hopeful and a very hardworking and visionary client. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy food and a hand cart for her kiosk.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina D. is from the town of Masabud, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has three infant children. Gina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan 6,000 from GDMPC. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Marianne

texts.en:
Marianne D. R. is a young mother who lives in a village located at Barangay Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya.

Marianne was in her 2nd year college when she married Mark Gil D. R. and they are now gifted with a child named Mark Anthony D. R. who is already two years old. It was difficult for them to adjust at first because neither of them had a stable job although they were thankful because their parents helped them to provide for their needs.

With the help of their parents, Marianne and her husband bought a tricycle which her husband uses to earn an income while Marianne is engaged in selling Avon products in their village. Marianne borrowed additional capital from ASKI to acquire those products which she sells to her neighbors and friends. According to her, she is able to earn a net income of Php 4,000 a month which she adds to her husband's income to acquire their daily needs and pay her weekly amortization.

Since her business is profitable, Marianne wants to continue it and to acquire additional items. When she paid back her first loan, she applied again, requesting an amount of Php 10,000 to be used in acquiring the said additional items. She is so thankful with this financial assistance because she has the opportunity to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To acquire additional items for her direct-selling business

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony F. is from the village of Cabalantuon, Manticao. He is 24 years old and single. To make a living, Anthony owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from  raising and selling hogs in the local community. Anthony has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

Anthony joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anthony is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional hogs. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feeds and additional hogs to raise

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S., 40, is married with two children. She lives with her husband and children in Sa Ang, Cambodia. S. sells fish at a local market in her province, and earns approximately $18 USD per day. Her husband works in the agriculture sector, raising cows and growing rice seasonally. He earns $3 USD per day.

The couple work hard every day in the field during the rainy season in order to ensure a good standard of living for the family. S. also has to commute to market every morning to sell fish to her existing customers because she hopes that her fish-selling business will help her to achieve a better standard of living. S. is asking for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase cows for her husband to raise more livestock.

loans.use: To purchase cows

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel C. is from the village of Don Jose Aguirre. She is 22 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Maricel owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling farm products, such as bananas and vegetables, in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Maricel joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be her second from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies and for her children education. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina G. is from the village of Masabud, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Angelina owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Angelina has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Angelina joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Zarif

texts.ru: Хайруллоев Зариф проживает в районе Абдурахмони Чоми. Возраст 39 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Зариф более 10 лет работает по специальности "механиком". Вот более 4 лет начал заниматся животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для покупки крупно рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Zarif H. lives in the Abdurahmon-Jomi region. He is 39 years old. He is married and has six children. Zarif has worked as a mechanic for more than ten years. As of four years ago he started doing animal husbandry. He feeds and sells cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy large cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
Ya N., 34, is single and lives with her family in Sa Ang, Cambodia. In total there are three members of her family, and N. has to take care of her elderly father. To make a living, N. runs a business designing and sewing clothes for people in her village. She is able to earn approximately $8 USD per day in revenue.

N.'s family is assisted by her younger sister who works as a hairdresser, earning an income of $6 USD per day. N. is seeking to improve her standard of living and expand her business during this economically difficult time. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of $1200 USD to purchase more fabrics for designing clothes to meet customer demand. She hopes that her future business plan will be successful so that she is able to generate more income for household use.

loans.use: To buy more fabric

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester U. is 47 years old and lives in the village of Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Feliciano and they are blessed with five children, all of whom are studying. Their eldest child is now in tertiary education while the others are in secondary education. Despite the economic crisis, they want their children to finish their studies and become successful in the future. 

The main source of income for Ester's family is from farming – they plant rice and corn. As an additional source of income, Ester set up a small sari-sari store (community-based general store) in their village with a small amount of capital. She usually purchases products for the store in the public market in Bayombong. As a fruit of her patience and sacrifice, she earns a net income of 3,500 PHP, which she uses to meet the family's daily needs and pay for the schooling of their children. Sending the children to school is very costly, which is why Ester wants her business to become more profitable. 

Ester is now borrowing PHP14,000 from KIVA lenders for the development of her store. She believes that with your financial assistance and with her efforts and sacrifices, she will be able to improve her small business.

loans.use: As additional capital for the improvement of her small sari-sari store

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin F. is from the village of Madasigon, Suarez. He is 36 years old and single. To make a living, Edwin owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. The main source of income for the business comes from selling mineral water. Edwin has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Edwin joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edwin is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be his first from HSPFI.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a 27-year-old married businesswoman with three children. She runs an entertainment business, the Salome Playstation, in the Mathare slums of Nairobi. The business shows movies and is in high demand with young people in the area. Salome is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to buy ice-cream making materials and maize flour for porridge.

Salome hopes to expand her business further and lead a better life. She says that through Kiva partner Faulu she has also learned the importance of saving. She describes herself as a hardworking and visionary client.

About Faulu Kenya
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Microfinance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy ice-cream making materials and maize flour

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn C. is married to Mr. Joel C. of Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is a responsible housewife who aims to improve their standard of living so that they can give their child a better future. Despite the hardships and difficulties of life, the couple still have strong faith and determination to achieve their goal. They believe that hard work and sacrifice will lead to progress and are therefore doing their best to earn more income for their child's future, and for their future children as well.

One means of earning income for the couple is barbecue and cup cake vending in their village. In addition, Jocelyn's husband sometimes does construction work. As a fruit of their patience and labor, they are now earning a net weekly income of 700 PHP from their small business. Since their weekly income is not sufficient for the needs of the family, it is important to increase their income. For this reason, Jocelyn wants to borrow additional capital of 5,000 PHP from Kiva partner ASKI to improve their small business. She is very confident that, with this financial assistance, she will be able to improve her business and increase their income.

loans.use: As additional capital to improve her food production business

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante M. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. He is 39 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Dante owns and operates a motorcycle service business. Dante has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Dante joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dante is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and accessories. This loan will be his first from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Zarif H. lives in the Abdurahmon-Jomi region. He is 39 years old. He is married and has six children. Zarif has worked as a mechanic for more than ten years. As of four years ago he started doing animal husbandry. He feeds and sells cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy large cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer
