loans.name: Huk

texts.en:
Huk Y., 63, is married and resides with her husband (pictured) in Sa Ang, Cambodia. She lives with one of her children who is married and employed in a local garment factory, earning an income of US$3 per day.

Y. is a housewife who takes care of the household chores while her husband is a motorbike repairman at a local market. Her husband is able to generate an income of approximately US$5 per day as their primary source of income for the family.

This couple is seeking to expand the husband’s current business and thus to improve their family’s standard of living. Therefore, Y. is asking for a loan of US$300 for her husband to purchase motorbike spare parts to meet his customers’ needs when their motorbikes break down.

loans.use: To buy motorbike spare parts for her husband's business

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: K. Philomène  est née en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Philomène vit depuis une trentaine d’année à Dowa, un quartier de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à ADOUEKONOU Emmanuel un chauffeur, Philomène est mère de quatre enfants, dont trois sont à sa charge. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. N’ayant jamais été à l’école, Philomène a commencé dès son bas-âge la vente d’huile à moteur et de gasoil à son domicile. Philomène s’approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. Philomène a obtenu antérieurement à ALIDé, deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Philomène sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et dans le but de mieux répondre aux besoins de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
K. Philomène was born in 1967 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  She has been living for some 30 years in Dowa, a district of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She is married to ADOUEKONOU Emmanuel, a chauffeur, and is the mother of four children, of whom three are in her care. Only some of them are in school.  The couple shares in covering family expenses.  Never having gone to school, Philomène started selling motor oil and diesel fuel in her home at an early age.  She stocks up in Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin.  She has obtained two ALIDé loans before which she has repaid.  She's requesting a third ALIDé loan in order to increase her capital fund with the goal of responding better to customer needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers of motor oil

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn R. is from the village of Don Jose Aguirre. She is 22 years old. Genelyn is married. To make a living, Genelyn raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Genelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years with approximate average monthly earnings of 4,000 Philippine pesos for these activities.

In 2009, Genelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to pay for services in cultivating the farm to increase crop yield. Genelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Genelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie E. is from the village of P-10, Tag-ibo, Iligan City. She is 40 years old. Josie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Josie operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She also runs a videoke (video karaoke) business. Josie has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Josie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Boimahmad

texts.ru: Боймахмад Сангов проживает в районе Абдурахмони Чоми. Возраст 49 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Два сына находятся в России на заработках. Сам Боймахмад более 5 лет занимается животноводством, т.е. откармливанием и продажей крупно рогатого скота. Кредит просит для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Boimahmad S. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is 49 years old. He is married and has four children. His two sons are now working in Russia. Boimahmad does animal husbandry for more than five years. He feeds and sells large cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large cattle

loans.name: Glorie

texts.en:
Glorie E. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 39 years old. Glorie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Glorie operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables in the local community. Glorie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Glorie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glorie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for vegetable vending. This will be the first loan taken out by Glorie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: As additional capital for vegetable vending

loans.name: Hoàng Thị's Group

texts.en:
H. Hoàng Thị (10107060006) is a 55 year-old female living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà Nội. H. is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Xuân Canh (4).

H. is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living H. raises livestock. Her main source of income is from raising and selling chickens. H. has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2006, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. H. successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.876.000 VND from SEDA that she used to expand her business. She now requests her 4th loan of 4.142.000 VND that she will also invest in her business. H. plans to use the additional revenue to improve the living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. Đào Thị X. (10107060002) is a 45 year-old female requesting a 5.886.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

2. Lê Thị T. (10107060003) is a 59 year-old female requesting a 5.014.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

3. Trần Thị T. (10107060004) is a 24 year-old female requesting a 4.142.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

4. Nguyễn Thị S. (10107060005) is a 50 year-old female requesting a 4.142.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

5. Nguyễn Thị H. (10107060007) is a 35 year-old female requesting a 4.142.000 VND loan to support her manufacturing business.

6. Nguyễn Thị T. (10107060008) is a 29 year-old female requesting a 4.142.000 VND loan to support her manufacturing business.

7. Nguyễn THị H. (10107060001) is a 37 year-old female who is requesting a 2.834.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

About SEDA
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

Note
To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


H. Hoàng Thị (10107060006) là 55 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà Nội. H. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 8 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Xuân Canh (4). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán. H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 3.500.000 VND. Vào 2006, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.876.000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.142.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Đào Thị X. (10107060002) là 45 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.886.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Lê Thị T. (10107060003) là 59 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.014.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 3. Trần Thị T. (10107060004) là 24 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.142.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 4. Nguyễn Thị S. (10107060005) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.142.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 5. Nguyễn Thị H. (10107060007) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.142.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất. 6. Nguyễn Thị T. (10107060008) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.142.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất. 7. Nguyễn THị H. (10107060001) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 2.834.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en: Tessie N. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 49 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Tessie owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Tessie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Vossin Rhode

texts.fr: L. Vossin Rhode est née en 1976 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Vossin Rhode vit depuis dix ans à Djassin à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Vossin Rhode est mariée à KOUKPO Anauld et est mère d’un enfant qui n’est pas encore scolarisé. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Il y a de cela cinq ans que Vossin Rhode mène comme activité la vente de chaussures, tissus et friperies au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo et à Cotonou. Vossin Rhode mène également comme activité secondaire la vente de produits de beauté. Vossin Rhode achète ses articles au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. Vossin Rhode a bien remboursé le premier crédit qu’elle a obtenu de ALIDé, et est à son deuxième crédit. Ce crédit lui permettra d’augmenter la taille de son activité et de la diversifier.
texts.en:
L. Vossin Rhode was born in 1976 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  For ten years, she has been living in Djassin in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She is married to KOUKPO Anauld and the mother of one child who is not yet in school.  The couple shares in covering family expenses.  Five years ago, Vossin Rhode ran a business selling shoes, fabrics, and second-hand clothing at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and in Cotonou.  She also ran a secondary business selling beauty products.  She buys her goods in Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin.  Vossin Rhode has repaid the first loan she obtained from ALIDé and is now on her second one.  This loan will enable her to expand her business and to diversify it.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes and various items (used clothing, etc.)

loans.name: Charlita

texts.en:
Parents are so concerned with the future of their children; they exert effort and sacrifice their time to earn a living for the sake of their children. Likewise, Mrs. Charlita M., with her husband, Mr. Benjamin M., of Barangay Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya, are striving hard to support the education of their five children. Despite the economic crisis, they still have the strong faith and determination to uplift their standard of living and give their children a better future.

The couple earn a living through farming. They cultivate their farm by planting fruits and vegetables for two harvests. Since harvesting takes a long time, they need to have another source of income to finance the schooling of their children. In this regard, Charlita engaged in selling vegetables and fruit in their village. She sells them through house to house delivery and also to the market through retail. Every week, she earns a net income of Php 700 which they utilize to acquire their daily basic needs and for the schooling of their children.

Since her weekly income is not sufficient for the needs of the family, Charlita wants to sell more vegetables to earn a higher income. In this regard, she wants to borrow additional capital of Php 5,000 from ASKI to be used in acquiring more products for her vending business. She hopes that, through the continuous support of ASKI, she will be able to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola is 42 years old and married with four children. She sells crates of drinks both wholesale and retail to her customers to make a living. She hopes for the loan of N170,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Liduena

texts.en:
63-year-old Liduena works with her husband on their farm. They have three children and the eldest is 33 years old.

At her age, Liduena is still strong enough to tend their farm. She hopes to succeed in life and give her family a better living.

Liduena applied for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI and will use this loan to finance her farm. She is hopeful that her dreams will come true.

loans.use: To use for farm financing

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru: Насруллоев Сафарали проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 45 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена домохозяйка. Дети несовершеннолетние. Сам Сафарали более 12 лет работает в местной таможне. Кредит просит для закупа скота, т.к. он более 16 лет занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот.
texts.en:
N. Safarali lives in the Kurgan-Tube region. He is 45 years old. He is married and has four children. His children are teenagers. Safarali works in the local customs for more than twelve years. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle as he has also been doing animal husbandry for more than sixteen years. He feeds and sells cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Mary Niza

texts.en: Mary Niza E. is from the town of Manticao. She is 29 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Mary Niza owns and operates a business raising livestock. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Mary Niza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en: Dominga B. is from the village of Gata Diot, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 73 years old, is widowed, and has twelve adult children. Dominga owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Dominga joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Mrs. Maria R. hopes and prays for all her children to finish school and most importantly to serve God. She is a 50-year-old married woman. She invested in books and now sells them for a living. She sells education and health books, and she is happy to say that out of her income from selling books, she has been able to send her children to school. She wants to help educate more people by selling more books. With that goal in mind, she applied to borrow Php18,000 to purchase books that are needed in her town. This loan will surely help Maria achieve her goals.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo is 48 years old and married with four children. She sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She hopes for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She is determined to improve her business and to lift her family above poverty. She says "Thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is 43 years old and a widow with five children.  She is engaged in a sari-sari store business (a community-based variety store) in her village located in San Andres, Aurora, Isabela. Being a single parent, she needs to work hard to provide the needs of her family.  Aside from selling basic commodities, she is also selling vegetables and snacks around their village. She is doing her best to give her children a good education.  

Rosalie is sending her youngest child to school. She is now in her fourth year of high school. Two of her children are working in Manila.  Some of her children are helping Rosalie financially, so that she can budget for their family needs and also for the maintenance of their farm.  She wants to improve her business, so she decided to borrow PHP8,000 from Kiva lenders.  She believes that with this amount, her business will continue to be profitable.

loans.use: Additional capital for improvement of her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth R. is from the village of Don Jose Aguirre. She is 26 years old. Elizabeth is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables to sell. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over five years with an approximate average monthly earnings of $150 from these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to pay for help in cultivating the land to increase crop yield. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and to improve their quality of life in the future. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Sourou Parfaite

texts.fr: A. Sourou Parfaite est née le 18 Avril 1981 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Sourou Parfaite vit depuis vingt deux ans à Houéyogbé un quartier de Porto-Novo. Mariée à ZOUNON Ignace, un peintre-auto, Sourou Parfaite est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à sa charge. Sourou Parfaite et Ignace vivent ensemble et supportent les charges de la famille. C’est depuis quinze ans que Sourou Parfaite vend des céréales au grand marché de Porto-Novo. Sourou Parfaite s’approvisionne en céréales à Ikpinlè au Sud du Bénin. Sourou Parfaite a bénéficié déjà d’un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux répondre aux demandes  de sa clientèle, Sourou Parfaite sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Sourou Parfaite was born on April 18, 1981 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of the Republic of Benin.  For 28 years, she has been living in Houéyogbé, a district of Porto-Novo.  She is married to ZOUNON Ignace, an automobile painter, and is the mother of three children, who are all in school and in her care.  She and Ignace live together and are meeting family expenses.  Sourou Parfaite has been selling grains at the grand marketplace of Porto-Nov for 15 years.  She stocks up on grains in Ikpinlè in southern Benin.  She has already benefited from an ALIDé loan, which she repaid.  To increase her capital funds and to respond better to the demands of her customers, she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains (sacks of corn, beans, and rice)

loans.name: Yetunde

texts.en: Yetunde is 45 years old and married with four children. She sells crates of drinks at both wholesale and at retail prices to her various customers. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says "Thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Azamhon

texts.ru: Азамхон Турсунов проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 33 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Азамхон по специальности "пекарь". Он имеет лепечешную, где печет лепешки. У него имеются постоянные покупатели. Кредит просит для ремонта и восстановления лепешечной.
texts.en:
Azamhom T. lives in the town of Qurgan-tube. He is 33 years old. He is married and has three children. His wife is a housewife. Azamhon's profession is a baker. He has a bakery where he makes flat breads. He has regular customers. He is asking for a loan to repair and restore his bakery.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For repair and restoration of bakery

loans.name: Rosinah

texts.en:
Rosinah is a 31-year-old married mother of two children living in Machakos, a small market town near Nairobi. She has run the Superstar Salon for the last six years and employs one person. She was previously a vegetable vendor and still earns some extra income through small-scale farming. She is requesting Kes. 30,000 to purchase Abuja braids, a hairdryer, hair relaxer, and shampoo. In the future, she hopes to open two more big salons and become a wholesale supplier of salon supplies. She describes herself as hardworking.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy braids, shampoo, hair relaxer, and a hair dryer.

loans.name: Laraba

texts.en: Laraba is 40 years old and married with two children. She sells colorful sarongs at various prices. This is the high season for the sales of sarongs, and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs a loan of N150,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane E. is from the village of Zone 1, Kabacsanan, Iligan City. She is 30 years old and married with four school-age children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling a variety of food products (including "bolad" or dried fish) in the local community. Her husband runs a motorcycle transport business. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $155 a month from these activities.

Mary Jane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Zone 1, Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase assortment

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria S. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 52 years old and married with two grown children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling vegetables in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $175 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Maria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Everlyn  Jepkemoi

texts.en:
Everlyn is 48 years old and married to Samson, who is a farmer. They have eight children. Her rental housing business is located in Eldoret. The majority of her clients are teachers and businessmen who are not residents of Eldoret, so they rely on Everlyn's rental houses.

She was introduced to KADET by a friend.

With the loan she is taking from KADET she intends to buy more construction materials and also to repair her houses. Her future dreams are to buy land within Eldoret and build residential houses.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase materials for construction of rental houses and to repair existing rental homes.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: D. H. Jeanne est née en 1974 à Katagon au Bénin où elle y vit depuis sa naissance. Mariée  à ZOKPENON Jérôme un conducteur de moto, Jeanne est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés et à sa charge. Les charges de la famille sont supportées ensemble par le couple. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Jeanne vend de façon ambulante des friperies. Jeanne vend également de la nourriture devant son portail à Katagon. Jeanne s’approvisionne au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo, et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Jeanne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. En vue d’augmenter son capital pour pouvoir agrandir son activité, Jeanne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. H. Jeanne was born in 1974 in Katagon, Benin, where she has been living since birth.  She is married to ZOKPENON Jérôme, a moto taxi driver, and is the mother of five children, who are all in school and in her care.  Family expenditures are covered jointly by the couple.  For a dozen years, Jeanne has been hawking second-hand clothing, as well as selling food in front of her door, in Katagon.  She stocks up at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and in Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin.  She is a former ALIDé client who has already benefited from two loans, which she repaid.  With regard to increasing her capital in order to be able to grow her business, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en:
Felipa does her best to earn a living for her family. She is married and has 8 children. Like any mother, she wants her kids to have proper education and finish school. She runs a general store and enjoys selling to her neighbors and other customers.

Felipa is in need of additional capital for her business. She is applying for a loan of Php 4,000 to buy goods for her store. This loan will be very helpful to Felipa and her business venture.

loans.use: adding to her inventory

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en: Adenike is 34 years old and married with 2 children. She sells VCDs and she also sells rechargeable phone cards to make a living. She hopes for the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene R. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 36 years old. Irene is married and has 2 children. The elder is school-aged and the other one is an infant. To make a living, Irene owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle passenger services to local community members. Irene is just starting this business.

In 2007, Irene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. Irene is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used payment of the motorcycle on installments used in the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Irene from PMPC. She plans to buy a motorcycle to be owned by the family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: payment of  motorcycle on installment plan

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en:
Diosdada is a rice farmer from Trinidad, Bohol. She is 49 years old, married, and has 4 children. She wants to be a good mother to all her kids and works hard for their education. Short of financial support for her farming business, she joined CEVI to take advantage of its financial services. She is requesting to borrow Php10,000, which she will use to finance her farm.

Diosdada will be delighted if her loan is granted because she wants her crops to be healthy and produce quality harvest.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Ndulu

texts.en:
Ndulu is a 36-year-old mother of three children living in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has run a kiosk selling fruit, sweets, airtime, and drinks for seven years. She also earns some added income through small-scale farming. She is requesting Kes. 30,000 to buy drinks, sweets, airtime, and washing powder. In the future, she hopes to expand into a wholesale business. She describes herself as “dedicated to work.”

About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy washing powder, sweets, airtime, and drinks for resale

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn E. is from the village of P-9, Luinab, Iligan City. She is 31 years old. Emelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Emelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products such as soap in the local community. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Emelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the ducation of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: P-9, Luinab, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.en: Cirilo, in blue polo, is a diligent fish vendor. Married and a father to nine children, he makes sure he exerts enough effort to feed them and supply the family’s daily needs. He also put up a general store to support his family. His need for capital pressed him to join Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He applied for a loan of Php 12,000. He will use this loan to buy fish and stock for his store.

loans.use: fish and inventory for his general store

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia loves gardening. She cultivates vegetables on her farm and sells her harvest at the market. She also feeds her children with her vegetables to keep them healthy. At 44, she has 10 kids with her husband, Medardo. One of her goals in life is to save up for the future of her children.

Cecilia is now requesting to borrow Php12,000 to finance her vegetable farm. She really wants this loan because she wants to sell healthy food to people in her town.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: R. Louise est née en 1985 à Katagon dans les collines au Bénin. Louise vit depuis dix ans à Katagon Anianli et est mariée à NOUDEHOUENOU Zamba, un vulganisateur. Louise et Zamba ont deux enfants tous scolarisés et vivant à leur charge. Louise est une coiffeuse qui mène également comme activité, la vente de produits de toilette à Anianli. Louise n'a jamais été à l'école et exerce cette activité depuis onze ans déjà. Louise achète ces produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Louise sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour accroître son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
R. Louise was born in 1985 in Katagon in Collines County in Bénin.  She has been living for ten years in Katagon Anianli and is married to NOUDEHOUENOU Zamba, a tire maker.  She and Zamba have two children who are both in school and dependents of theirs.   Louise is a hairdresser who also runs a business selling bath items, in Anianli.  She never attended school and has already been in this business for eleven years.  She purchases these items in Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin, and at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo.  She is a former ALIDé client who has benefited from two loans before, which she repaid.  Louise is requesting a third loan from ALIDé for growing her business and for satisfying her customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy personal care products

loans.name: Francis' Group

texts.en:
Francis N. is the leader of her group in Kyaliwajjala. She is a hard working and married lady with four children all in primary school and she also takes care of one dependent. 

Francis has a retail shop and a bar in Kyaliwajjala that has been running since 1995.  She is grateful that the loans have helped her business to succeed through increased recapitalization. In a week, Francis can make 60,000/= as profit which helps her expand her business further. 

During the day, she is mostly into shop-keeping and in the evening, customers come in to have a bottle of beer or two. Hence she makes a double income every day. Francis works so hard to ensure that she has an educated family. 

With her loan Francis hopes to boost her bar business by buying more chairs for her customers to sit on.

loans.use: Buy chairs for patrons and expand business.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose  sells provisions in front of her house; she uses the profit she makes for her family needs. She is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She has been in the business for the past 5 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more provision to sell

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida G. is from the village of P-24, Tag-ibo, Iligan City. She is 32 years old. Nida is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Nida owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Nida has been engaged in her business for over 3 years. In 2009, Nida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Nida is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to improve the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand into other businesses.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: P-24, Tag-ibo, Dalipuga, Iligan City, Lanao del No

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 31 years old and married with two children. She sells drinks and has been in the business for the past three years. She uses part of her profit for family upkeep and invests the rest.

Esther hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Joan's Group

texts.en:
Joan B. is the leader of her group in Kampala. She is 63 years old with 5 children.

Joan is a hard working lady with a 16-year-old crafts shop in Crafts Africa on Buganda Road, where she sells art and crafts. Her customers are mostly foreigners along with some community people. She caters to grandchildren and cousins as well. 

She needs a loan to buy more crafts, although she makes some of them herself. The loan will also help her to look after her home. 

Joan is grateful for her lending group because she is able to access loans through it and it teaches its members the disciplines of saving and teamwork.

loans.use: To buy more crafts to sell.

loans.name: Pelsie

texts.en:
Mrs. Pelsie V. lives in Brgy, Menez, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Married to a tricycle (rickshaw) driver, with 4 children, Pelsie has managed to help her family make ends meet with a small general store she has been operating for 7 years. Recently she has started electronic loading (the selling of mobile phone airtime credits) to increase her income.

As years pass, Pelsie realizes that it is important for her to grow her business so she can continue to meet the growing demands of her family. A better future, comfortable life, and a little savings for times of emergency are what Pelsie looks forward to.

A loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory for her general store (her 12th loan cycle with NWTF-Project Dungganon) will make this dream a little closer. About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital.

loans.name: Rema

texts.en:
Rema C. is a 30 year-old mother to two children (ages six and seven) in the village of Sitio San Juan Brgy Caradioan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Her husband is a pastor in their local community church. As a mother, she dreams of giving her children a brighter future, of sending them to school and helping them finish their studies, and of uplifting her family's living. She also wants to help her husband defray household expenses. To address these things and prepare for the future, Rema decided to start her own business so she can make an income to support her dreams in life. That's why in January 2004 she became an entrepreneur and joined NWTF-Project Dungganon. With her first loan Rema started a general store to have an easy income and the fast turnover of her capital. She was very happy because her earnings helped meet the needs of her children and family. Her loan and business grew for 3 years, when she started other businesses like the load retailer (phone cards), selling gasoline, and networking of Avon Products. These businesses are a big help for her family. She was able to earn 3000 PHP per month. Now she says that her businesses are a big contribution toward achieving her dreams. Rema used her previous loan of 18000 PHP as additional working capital for her general store. She paid on a weekly basis and it was fully paid in full and on time. Now she will use her 8th cycle loan of 19000 PHP for her general store and other businesses. She will save the additional income for the education of her children. About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store and other businesses.

loans.name: Olohountognin Séraphine

texts.fr: O. Olohountognin Séraphine est née en 1979 à Zoukpa à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, où elle y réside depuis sa naissance. Mariée à KOUNOU Jérôme, un soudeur, Olohountognin Séraphine est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Olohountognin Séraphine vit seul avec ses enfants ; elle supporte seule les charges de ses enfants. C’est depuis dix ans que Olohountognin Séraphine mène comme activité la vente de tissus et de bassines. Olohountognin Séraphine fait ses approvisionnements à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Olohountognin Séraphine a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Pour augmenter ses marchandises et sa clientèle, en vue de mieux répondre aux besoins de ses deux enfants, Olohountognin Séraphine sollicite à nouveau auprès de ALIDé un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Olohountognin Séraphine O. was born in 1979 in Zoukpa in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, where she has lived all her life. She is married with Jérôme Kounou, a welder, and the mother of two children who attend school. Olohountognin Séraphine lives alone with her children and provides alone for them.

Olohountognin Séraphine has been selling cloths and basins for ten years. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She had so far two loans from Alidé, which she repaid on schedule. Since she wants to increase her inventory and expand her clientele, with the aim to better provide for her two children, she came again to Alidé and applied for a third loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloths and basins

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en: K. Sarah is a business lady managing two businesses: a poultry business and a business selling fruits and vegetables in the city centre in Kampala. She is a hardworking devoted married lady with ten children and six dependants. Sarah has been operating the businesses for a very long time, except the fruit selling business which is the most recent one. She is grateful for her loans because she has been able to educate all her children through university and most of them are now bank managers and accountants. Sarah needs a loan to buy more feed and chicks for farm expansion, as well as to buy more fruit for resale. Sarah is the leader of her lending group in Nansana.

loans.use: Buying more chicken feed and chicks for farm expansion

loans.name: Sèdo Célestine

texts.fr: H. Sèdo Célestine  est née le 10 Octobre 1980 à Djègan-Daho un quartier de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Sèdo Célestine  vit depuis dix ans dans ce quartier de Porto-Novo et est mariée à FASSINOU Hyacinthe un gros transporteur. Le couple n’a qu’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par les deux conjoints. Sèdo Célestine  est une couturière qui mène également comme activité la vente de maïs et de charbon à son domicile. Il y a huit ans de cela que Sèdo Célestine  mène cette activité. Sèdo Célestine  fait ses approvisionnements à Ikpinlè et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Sèdo Célestine  sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé pour accroître son fonds de roulement et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
H. Sedo Celestine is born October 10, 1980 in Djegan-Daho, a neighborhood of Porto Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Sedo Celestine has been living in this neighborhood for ten years and is married to FASSINOU Hyacinthe a major transporter. The couple has only one child who is in school. The couple support each other with the family expenses. Sedo Celestine is a seamstress who also does business in selling maize and charcoal at home. It's been eight years Seda has been in this business. Sedo gets her supplies at Ikpinle and in the market of Ouando in Porto-Novo. She is an old customer of ALIDe who already benefitted from two loans that she repaid correctly. Sedo Celestine is requesting a third loan from ALIDe to expand her working capital and to satisfy mostly her customers.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of maize and charcoal

loans.name: C5209 Dukundane Group

texts.en:
Immaculee K. is 42 years old and married with 12 children. She lives in Nyarugenge district, in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, where her small shop selling a variety of food products and items for the home has been located since 2003.  Immaculee sells different kinds of products ranging from: salt, sugar, rice, potatoes, juice, water, cosmetics products, cooking oil, to cleaning supplies, etc… And her small but busy shop is open every day from 6AM to 9PM. 

She is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to add to her working capital, purchase more inventory and provide more products to her existing customers and hopefully attract new customers as well. She projects that her monthly net profit will increase significantly over the current level of 30,000 RWF per month.  With this extra income, Immaculee plans to continue to expand her business offerings and grow her enterprise.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of new products for her store

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en:
The group leader, K. Margaret, was unable to be in the group picture, but she is shown in the small picture on the upper left. 

K. Margaret is a business lady with many businesses that she runs with the help of her children and other employed workers. Margaret is a widow. She has rental income bringing in a monthly fee. She has a hardware shop selling building materials. She makes pancakes for sale every day from her home as well as making juice from yellow bananas that she sells in jerry cans in Bakuli, Kampala. She decided to join all these businesses because she always wanted the best for herself and her family, especially after the death of her husband. Margaret is a hardworking and devoted lady. 

Margaret is the leader of her lending group. She is one of the founding members of the group. She is grateful that she has been able to educate her children using proceeds from her businesses and, currently, she still has two children in school. Margaret needs a loan to help recapitalize her businesses, especially the hardware shop. She will buy ingredients for making the pancakes as well as more bananas for making the juice.

loans.use: To restock a hardware shop and buy raw materials for making pancakes and bananas for making juice

loans.name: Rasool 16 Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Rasool wants to receive a loan for a car parts shop to buy the essential materials. Shanaz wants to take out a loan for her husband’s general store to complete his stock. Seema wants to take out a loan for her tailoring business in order to buy a new sewing machine, because she has lots of problems with the old one.

This is the Rasool 16 Group. Ghulam Rasool is the group leader. The three members have requested a group loan of 42,000 afghanis. Finally, they would like to thank the Kiva lenders a lot.

loans.use: To buy requirements for a car parts shop

loans.name: C3754 Imanzi Group

texts.en: Emmanuel K. is 40 years old and married with one child who is 8 years old. He lives in Kicukiro district where his business has been located since 2008.  His business is open from 8AM to 6PM seven days per week.   Emmanuel is group leader, respected in his community, and is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business and sell more types of clothing for different styles and sizes. If his strategy of growth pays off, it will help him to save money so that he can buy his own house.  His monthly profit is currently 50,000RWF (US$ 90) which he explains is not enough to meet his needs and allow for owning his own home.

loans.use: New styles of clothing and sizes

loans.name: Dolor

texts.en:
26-year-old Dolor M. lives with her husband Crisanto, a restaurant employee, and their only child, in Malibay, Pasay City.
 
Dolor has been working hard on her piggery business.  She raises pigs to get income to support her family. She also sells fresh pork meat.  She brings her pigs to the butcher when they are ready for slaughtering.  She also finds time to manage a rickshaw (pedicab) operation.  All these business activities account for her monthly income of P24,000.00.

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2001.  She has a pending application for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of P30,000.00 to infuse fresh capital into her business.
 
Dolor hopes to add a canteen business to her existing ones.  She also wants to have a meat stall in the nearby public market.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to infuse fresh capital into her business

loans.name: Robinah's Group

texts.en:
N. Robinah is a hardworking, determined and friendly lady with a retail shop business that she has been running for over 10 years, plus having a restaurant where she sells breakfast, lunch and supper. Robinah is the mother of 7 children (of which 5 are still in school) and she takes care of other siblings. She started with the retail shop and only opened the restaurant after making some savings with the help of a loan. She is seeking another loan with the hope that it will help her recapitalize her business and make more profit out of the increased stock. 
Robinah is the leader of her lending group in Nyanama.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods and buy foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: C3753 Duhugurane Group

texts.en:
Delphine N. is 38 years old and married with five children, ages 5 through 12.  Additionally, she cares for two dependents ages 15 and 20.  

Delphine lives in Nyarugenge district in the capital city of Kigali where her business selling a wide variety of produce has been located for the past  10 years.  She has proven her business ability with a successful 10-year track record! The business is open every day from 5AM to 7PM.
 
Delphine is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business and buy more produce in greater volume and at lower prices so that she earns more profit.  Previously, her monthly profit was 100,000 RWF (US$ 175 approximately). With this extra profit she hopes to earn, she plans to set aside money to buy her own house.

loans.use: Purchasing greater quantities of vegetables for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy animal skins to make shoes

loans.name: Febe

texts.en:
Febe B. is from the village of Sta. Filomena. She is 48 years old, married, and has 4 children. The first three are adult-aged while the youngest is school-aged.  To make a living, Febe owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. The primary source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Febe has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Febe joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Febe is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Febe from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and to support the education of her youngest child. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
53-year-old Victoria A. lives in Maricaban, Pasay City.  Her husband Guillermo, 59, has just retired from work.  They have three children.
 
Victoria has been repacking spices in her home for fifteen years now.  Spices such as black pepper, dried laurel leaves, and garlic are repacked in small plastic bags and distributed to store owners for retail.  Victoria earns P4,000.00 a month.  Her profits support the daily needs of her family, especially medication for a sick child.  

Victoria has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2005 and is now on her 15th loan cycle.  She applied for a new loan in the amount of P11,000.00 to buy raw materials for her business.

Victoria wants her children to finish their college education, and hopes to establish a bigger repacking factory of her own. 

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for her business

loans.name: Flavia's Group

texts.en:
N. Flavia, the leader of this lending group, makes chicken feed. At the moment, all Flavia’s children are out of school but she helps to take care of some orphans. She is a hardworking lady.

Flavia makes chicken feed from fresh animal blood, shells and bones. She employs people to go to Lufula slaughterhouses to collect the fresh blood in cans. She boils this with ingredients from Ugachick Poultry Breeders Limited in Gayaza, as an independent producer. Once done, she sells to Ugachick itself, although the payments take two weeks to come through. This is one reason she also sells to other firms that pay instant cash for her to remain in business.

Her previous loan helped her renovate her recently built house and now she needs a loan to help buy more raw materials for her business. She also wants to put a concrete floor in her house to get rid of the dust. She is very grateful for her previous loans and those to come.

loans.use: To buy materials for her chicken feed business and cement for making a concrete floor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, soap, sardines and other foods and beauty products

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta G. is from the village of Palao, Iligan City. She is 34 years old. Marietta is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Marietta owns and operates a service-based business specifically providing manicure and pedicure services in their local community. Marietta is just starting this business.

Marietta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marietta is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional materials used in providing the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marietta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional supplies and materials for her manicure and pedicure services

location.town: Palao, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: Z. Bernadette est née en Août 1969 et vit depuis neuf ans à Danto, un quartier de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à KOHOUN Philippe, Bernadette est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à sa charge. Le couple prend ensemble en charge les dépenses de la famille. Ayant abandonné les classes au secondaire, Bernadette mène depuis près de cinq ans comme activité la vente de bouillie(aliment fait à base d’amidon de maïs ou de mil) accompagnée de pâté (fait à base de farine de blé). Bernadette vend aussi des tissus. Bernadette fait ses approvisionnements à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Bernadette vend la bouillie et les pâtés au CEG Danto à Porto-Novo. Mais c’est au marché Ouando que Bernadette vend ses tissus. Bernadette est à son premier crédit à ALIDé. Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux satisfaire la demande de ses clients, Bernadette sollicite ce crédit auprès de ALIDé.  Bernadette envisage plus tard acheter une parcelle.
texts.en:
Bernadette Z. was born in August of 1969 and has lived for nine years in Danto, a neighborhood of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Married to Philippe Kohoun, Bernadette is the mother of four children who are all in school, two of whom she is currently supporting. The couple takes care of the family expenses together. Having dropped out of school at the secondary level, for almost five years Bernadette has been selling fabric and "bouillie" (cornstarch or millet based food) accompanied by pâté (made with a wheat flour base). Bernadette also sells fabric. Bernadette gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin and in the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Bernadette sells her bouillie in the Danto school in Porto-Novo, but she sells her fabric in Ouando. This is Bernadette's first loan with Alidé. Bernadette is requesting this loan from Alidé to increase her working capital and to better satisfy her customer's needs. In the future Bernadette plans to purchase a plot of land.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs, de sorgho et de farine de blé ainsi que des tissus.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice, oil, beans and other food products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase corn

loans.name: Lovi

texts.fr: Cette femme est une résidente du quartier logoté,  elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Elle exerce comme activité la couture, elle a associé à son commerce la vente des articles de mercerie. Elle travaille dans son propre atelier, le revenu qu’elle gagne de son commerce lui permet de contribuer aux charges de la famille. Son stock d’articles de mercerie étant épuisé, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter un carton de fils à coudre, des fermetures, 6 boîtes de boutons et divers articles de mercerie.
texts.en:
Lovi A. S. lives in the Logoté district, she is married and has two children. She is a seamstress and she also sells sewing supplies. She works in her own shop and the money she makes enables her to help take care of her family's expenses. Since her stock of sewing supplies is low, she needs to purchase more and is requesting a loan through WAGES so she can purchase a box of sewing thread, zippers, six boxes of buttons, and various other sewing supplies.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sewing supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pharmaceutical products

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine L. is from the village of Miputak. She is 32 years old. Josephine is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, operating a mini-restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving local foods to customers in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used for additional working capital. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Josephine from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for additional working capital

loans.name: Ayitédji Joséphine

texts.fr: N. Ayitédji Joséphine est née vers 1956 à Ifangni, village situé à proximité de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Ayitédji Joséphine vit depuis treize ans au quartier Danto à Porto-Novo. Mariée à KODJO Paul, Ayitédji Joséphine est mère de quatre enfants, dont un seulement est à sa charge. Certains de ses enfants sont scolarisés. Ayitédji Joséphine et Paul supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Ayant arrêté les classes au cours primaire, Ayitédji Joséphine s’est très tôt mise à vendre pour subvenir à ses besoins.  En effet, il y a vingt sept ans déjà que Ayitédji Joséphine vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs, sauce de tomate, accompagnés de poissons frits) et de l’amuse gueule (fait à base de farine de blé) au CEG Danto. Ayitédji Joséphine est également une couturière qui a son atelier de couture à son domicile. Ayitédji Joséphine fait ses emplettes au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est pour la première fois que Ayitédji Joséphine sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, pour renforcer son activité et accroître son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Ayitédji Joséphine N. was born about 1956 in Ifangni, a town located near to Porto Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Ayitédji Joséphine has lived for thirteen years in the neighborhood of Danto in Porto Novo. She is married to Paul Kodjo. Ayitédji Joséphine is the mother of four children, of which only one is in her care. Some of her children attend school. Ayitédji Joséphine and Paul bear together the family expenses. Having quit primary school, Ayitédji Joséphine began selling very early to provide for her needs. In fact, for twenty seven years already Ayitédji Joséphine has la nourriture (pate of corn, tomato sauce, accompanied by fried fish) and l’amuse gueule (made from a wheat flour base) in the CEG Danto. Ayitédji Joséphine is also a dressmaker that has her sewing workshop in her residence. Ayitédji Joséphine makes her purchases in the Ouando market of Porto Novo. This is the first time that Ayitédji Joséphine has requested a loan with ALIDé, to build her business and increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn, fried fish and condiments (tomato sauce, onions, hot peppers, etc.)

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes C. is a 31-year-old mother of five, all of whom are attending school. She has been in various business for the last nine years. She manages her own sari-sari (general) store located at their house while her husband, Maximillano, 32, provides a helping hand in taking care of their piggery business. Agnes joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only last year but has been enjoying the many social benefits it supplies to community members. Agnes is applying for a new loan of P10,000 from the cooperative with which she plans to venture into a computer shop business. To start, she will use her new loan to purchase a computer. Agnes hopes to venture into opening an Internet shop soon. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy a computer for her new business

loans.name: Kipkemboi

texts.en:
Kipkemboi is 45 years old, married and blessed with five children. His clothing business is located at the Flax center in Eldoret.

He heard of KADET, a Kiva partner, when he first visited Eldoret Town to ask about Microfinance and their products.

With the loan Kipkemboi is taking from KADET, he intends to add more clothes to his clothing business, which includes bedsheets, shorts, trousers and dresses for both children and adults. His dream is to open a wholesale clothing business once his children reach high school.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more clothing stock to his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase khaki fabric in order to tailor clothes for resale.

loans.name: Latifatou Adèle

texts.fr: H. Latifatou Adèle est née en 1967 à Katagon au Bénin. Latifatou Adèle est depuis quatre ans au quartier Danto à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à DOSSA Nicaise un gendarme, Latifatou Adèle est mère de cinq enfants et a un enfant en plus à sa charge. Tous ses enfants sont scolarisés. Latifatou Adèle et Nicaise supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Latifatou Adèle n’a jamais été à l’école ; il y a environs six ans qu’elle a commencé la vente des divers (pâtes alimentaires, biscuits, piles, sucre, savons, conserves, bougies, farine de manioc). Latifatou Adèle vend également de l’igname et a une boutique à son domicile où elle vend ses produits. Latifatou Adèle s’approvisionne à Kétou, à proximité de Porto-Novo, et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et aussi sa clientèle, Latifatou Adèle sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Latifatou Adèle H. was born in 1967 in Katagon Benin. Latifatou Adèle has lived for four years in the Danto neighborhood of Porto Novo, administrative capital of the Benin. She is married to Nicaise Dossa, a policeman. Latifatou Adèle is the mother of five children and has one more child in her care. All her children attend school.
