Latifatou Adèle and Nicaise bear together the family expenses. Latifatou Adèle never attended school; it has been about six years since she began the sale of goods (pasta, cookies, batteries, sugar, soap, canned goods, candles, manioc flour). Latifatou Adèle also sells yams and has a shop in her residence where she sells her products. Latifatou Adèle supplies herself at Kétou, near Porto Novo, and in the Ouando market of Porto Novo. She is a former customer of ALIDé that already benefitted from two loans that she repaid well. To increase her working capital and also her clientele, Latifatou Adèle requests a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of coal for wood and various other supplies for resale.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta G. is from the village of Barangay Uno. She is 60 years old and married with four grown children. To make a living, Loreta owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Loreta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loreta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her fifth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Lucienne

texts.fr: D. Lucienne est née en 1983 à Allagba au Bénin. Lucienne réside depuis dix ans à Takon Aïdjèdo à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Lucienne est mariée à ZANMENOU Barthélémy et est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Lucienne n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a six ans que Lucienne a commencé la vente de nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce et de poissons frits) de façon ambulante. Lucienne fait ses approvisionnements au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Lucienne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Afin de diversifier son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Lucienne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Lucienne D. was born in 1983 in Allagba, Bénin. Lucienne has lived for ten years in the Takon Aïdjèdo area of Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. Lucienne is married to Barthélémy Zanmenou and is the mother of two children who both attend school. The couple share together the family expenses. Lucienne never went to school. It has been six years since Lucienne began to sell nourriture (rice with sauce and fried fish) on foot. Lucienne makes her purchases at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Lucienne is a former client of ALIDé who has already benefitted from two loans which she repaid well. In order to diversify her business and better satisfy her clients, Lucienne requests a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and condiments for sauce (tomatoes, onions, hot peppers)

loans.name: Komlanvi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité la vente des produits cosmétiques, il exerce ce commerce de façon ambulante. Pour pouvoir gagner plus de profits sur ses ventes, il s’approvisionne à Accra cela lui permet de gagner plus de profits sur ses ventes. Sa clientèle grandit de plus en plus vite, pour pouvoir tous les satisfaire et convenablement, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des produits cosmétiques. Etant célibataire, ce commerce lui permet de subvenir à ses propres charges.
texts.en:
This gentleman sells cosmetic products as a street vendor. By purchasing his supplies in Accra, Ghana, he is able to earn a higher profit on his sales. His clientele is increasing more and more quickly and in order to meet their demand, he is requestng a loan from WAGES to purchase more cosmetic products. He is a single gentleman and this business allows him to support himself.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of cosmetic products

loans.name: Agnès

texts.fr: K. Agnès est née en 1984 à Katagon au Bénin. Agnès vit depuis dix ans à Takon Aïdjèdo, un quartier de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à ZANMENOU Barthélémy un vendeur d'essence frelaté, Agnès est mère de quatre enfants. Les enfants en âge d'être scolarisés le sont. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Agnès n'a jamais été à l'école et mène depuis huit ans déjà comme activité, la transformation d'huile de palme et la préparation d'akassa (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs) à son domicile. Agnès s'approvisionne à Takon et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo, et vend ses produits au marché Ouando. Agnès est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Pour augmenter le volume de son activité afin de capitaliser d'économies, Agnès sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Agnès ambitionne plus tard acheter sa propre parcelle grâce aux bénéfices qu'elle tirerait de ses ventes.
texts.en:
Agnès Kodga was born in 1984 in Katagon in Benin. For the past ten years, Agnès has been living in Takon Aïdjèdo, a district of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to Barthélémy Zanmenou, who sells gasoline, Agnès is the mother of four children. The children are of school age and attend school. The couple supports their family together. Agnès has never gone to school and has for the last eight years been in the business of transforming palm oil and preparing akassa (a local food made from corn starch) from home. Agnès stocks up in Takon and at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and sells her products at the Ouando market. Agnès is a former client of Alidé and has already benefitted from two loans, which she has repaid. In order to increase her business in order to save, Agnès is seeking a third loan with Alidé. Agnès hope to be able to buy a plot of land in the future with the profits she will make from her sales.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm nuts and bags of corn

loans.name: Lydia Wangeci

texts.en: Lydia Wangeci W. has owned the Lydia Barber Shop for five years and has one employee.  Her store is well located in a busy area and her clients are men and children. Her business challenges are local competition and a lack of funds for expanding her small room.   She is using the loan of KES 20,000 to buy two machines for her barber shop and some fruits to sell over the holidays. She is married with four children ranging from four years to twenty-two years. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to expand her business in a way that she will be serving prominent people.  She is friendly, humble and loyal.

loans.use: To purchase two machines for the barber shop and fruit for the holidays

loans.name: Bugolo Zibalaatudde A Group

texts.en:
Miriam H. started a clothing shop five years ago that has experienced high levels of growth in recent years. She is 32 years old and married with six kids, all enrolled in primary school. In order to keep up with customer demand, she is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings to purchase more inventory. She is very hardworking and hopes her business will continue to grow so she may one day be able to pay for her children to be university educated.
Miriam H. is the leader of her group in Lugazi.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for a clothing shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more pharmaceutical products to improve business.

loans.name: Tausi's Group

texts.en:
Tausi N. is a fishmonger who is based in Kucondo but sells her stock in Tororo; there, she can demand high prices because of the city’s distance from the lake. She is the leader of her group in Lugozi. Tausi is married with six children, who are between 10 and 27 years old; additionally, she cares for the two children of her departed sister. 

Tausi would like to use the loan of 1,000,000 USH to repair some fishing boats in her fleet, which would allow her to transport more fish to Tororo. She believes that such actions will yield her higher profits. One day, Tausi hopes to be able to afford a permanent house for her family. She has actually already bought the land; she just needs a bit more money with which to begin construction.

loans.use: repairing her fishing boats

loans.name: Joweria's Group

texts.en:
Joweria Balugamberia is the leader of her group in Lugozi. She is involved in retail and has owned her own shop for 5 years. The 200,000 USH the shop currently generates per week in profits allows her to care for her seven children and the three orphans for whom she cares.

Recently, prices for goods have been higher; consequently, she would like to use the loan of 1,500,000 USH to remain well supplied. People choose to shop with her because her prices are good and because she always has what the customer needs. Joweria hopes that her business will continue to expand and that all of her kids will be raised to be good citizens of Uganda.

loans.use: restocking her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more goods to improve business.

loans.name: Tenneh

texts.en:
Tenneh S. is a 43-year-old business woman and a widow with four children aged 1 to 21 years old. Their educational levels are from 6th grade to a sophomore student at the university. She also cares for a sibling. Tenneh is a 9th grade drop-out due to poverty. She and her family live in the Steven Tolbert estate, an estate built by the government for Liberians who can’t afford an apartment or rent.

Tenneh‘s business is the sale of general goods like baby things, perfumes, body lotions, jewelery, and so on. She buys them wholesale from neighboring Guinea and sells them at retail prices in the Red-Light market, the largest retail market in Monrovia, Liberia. She has been running this business for twenty-one years and hoping to expand to a bigger store. Tenneh started with LD18,000 that was given to her by her late husband, and has been taking her business very seriously, because it is the only means of income for her and her children. She has been facing theft problems, but because she develops good relationships with her customers, their numbers increase day by day.

Tenneh needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a better education and of building a house for them in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to improve business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more provisional goods to improve business.

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee U. is 33 years old and is a widow with three children aged 3, 7 and 13. She also cares for an additional dependent who lives with the family. Immaculee and her family live in Gatsibo district, in the Eastern Province of Rwanda.

In 2004, Immaculee opened a restaurant and employs two persons in her business. Her restaurant is open every day from 6:00 in morning to 8:00 in evening.

Immaculee is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to have sufficient working capital to purchase modern equipment for her restaurant. With this loan she hopes to increase her business, which will help her to serve more customers.

loans.use: To purchase moden equipment for her restaurant

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a 45-year-old married woman with three children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria.

She sells paper and aluminum to make a living. She has been in the business for a long time. Gloria is a hard working woman and she is determined to lift her business and her family out of poverty. Gloria hopes for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more paper and aluminum to sell.

She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more paper and aluminum to sell

loans.name: Philly's Group

texts.en:
Philly L. is 27 years old and the leader of his group in Lugazi. He has been running his shop for 10 years and uses all the profits generated from the business to pay the school fees of his brothers and sisters (he has 4 sisters and 1 brother). At his shop one can find a variety of items, including, but not limited to, soap, biscuits, cola and shoe polish.

Recently the prices of goods have gone up, so Philly has had to raise the prices in his store. This is affecting business adversely, but Philly is confident that sales will soon recover. In the meantime, he would like to use the loan to maintain his inventory. "The competition is tough," Philly says; in order to retain his customer base he has to offer incentives, like a free sweet with a purchase larger than 5,000 USH. Philly is incredibly hardworking and hopes that he will be able to continue supporting the education of his siblings, even at the university level.

loans.use: increasing inventory

loans.name: Bosco

texts.en:
Bosco R. K. is 39 years old and is married with seven children aged 1 through 12. He also cares for an additional dependent that lives with the family. Bosco and his family live in Gatsibo district in the Eastern Province of Rwanda.

Bosco has had his beverage shop since 2006. His business is well located and busy most of the time. He employs three people in his successful beverage/soft drink retail business. His shop is open every day from 6:00 in morning to 6:00 in evening.

Bosco is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva in order to have sufficient working capital to purchase more soft drinks in greater quantities at better prices for his store. With this loan he hopes to increase his business, which will help him to serve more customers and hopefully attract new ones as well, and provide more food for his family.

loans.use: To buy more Fanta and other soft drinks

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is a 27-year-old married woman with three children between 4 and 6 years of age. She also takes care of additional family members. She rents a one-room house where she lives with five people. The family has access to electricity but has no piped water.

She owns a stall where she sells second hand clothing. She doesn’t pay for transportation costs to and from shopping because she works at the same market where she does her shopping. She works in the outskirts of Kampala, where on average she receives 20 customers a day. Harriet has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for five years, now servicing her tenth loan, and working with the same group mates.

Harriet uses public transport to and from home to work. Her challenges include defaulters and the ever-increasing prices of second hand clothes. Harriet wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothing. She is hopeful of seeing her business grow stronger and wants to start selling only on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothing

loans.name: Sumini

texts.en:
Sumini is a 45-year-old married woman with ten children between the ages of 4 and 20 years. She owns a four-room house where she lives with twelve people. Sumini takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

She owns a stall where she sells chapati (flatbread) and other samosas (filled pastry). Sumini doesn’t pay for transportation costs to and from shopping because she works in the same market where she does her shopping. On average she receives 40 customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. Sumini has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for five years, now servicing her tenth loan, and working with the same group mates. Sumini uses public transport to and from home to work. Her challenges include defaulters and the ever-increasing prices of baking powder and cooking oil.

Sumini wants to use this loan to buy more baking powder and jerrycans of cooking oil. She is hopeful of seeing her business grow stronger, and she would like to start selling chapati to different areas, as well as employing four people.

loans.use: To buy more cooking ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The client is a 30-year-old male and is married with one child. The client has been running a tailor’s shop for five years. The shop has a superb reputation in the city. With this loan the client is planning to purchase a sewing machine, fabric and yarn, which will help him increase his income. He intends to soon hire an assistant to help him around his shop.

loans.use: purchasing fabric and a sewing machine

loans.name: Mrangirangi Group

texts.en:
Frederick M., age 30, is married and has two children, both girls. His daughers’ names are Fidelis and Felix, and they are both under two years old. Frederick has an electrical goods shop where he sells and repairs second-hand TVs and radios. He also installs electricity in homes. He has had this business since 2006, and works from 8 am until 6 pm daily. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $90.

This will be Frederick’s fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. With his previous loans, Frederick was able to expand his business from one office to two, and he has repaid all previous loans successfully.  He hopes to use this loan to invest in new TVs to sell at his business, and also to buy more used TVs and radios from Zanzibar. He travels to Zanzibar two times a year to buy more items to sell. Frederick hopes to use his extra profits from this expansion in his business to help his family with the household expenses and to save for the future. Frederick says his life has changed a lot because of micro-loans from Tujijenge. Where he used to only be able to buy one or two parts for a TV at a time, he can now invest in several at one time.
	
Frederick will share this loan with his loan group, Mrangirangi (meaning “many colors” in Swahili), which totals 17 members. The members of the group will receive loans for a variety of businesses that include tailoring shops, carpentry services, food vending, and “table top” stands where fresh fruit and vegetables are sold. The group members will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Frederick is front and center wearing a white shirt.

loans.use: New TVs to expand his electronics store

loans.name: Bolanla

texts.en: Bolanla is 42 years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells all types of sarongs on a wholesale and retail basis to her customers. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the requirements of her clients. Bolanla hopes for the loan amount of 150,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for the financial support

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah is 52 and married with nine children between the ages of 19 and 35. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house, where she is staying with 12 people. Hadjah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. 

She owns a bar, selling beer and other drinks. She doesn’t pay transport costs to and from shopping because she buys from the place of her work. On average, she receives 20 customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for 10 years and with MCDT for five years. She is servicing her 10th loan, working with the same group mates. 

Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season, because when it rains very few customers come for a beer. Hadjah wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and soda plus other drinks. She aspires to see her business grow stronger and to start selling only on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Adejoku

texts.en: Adejoku sells rechargeable phone cards and VCDs. She is 33 years old and married with three children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. Adejoku is a hardworking woman and she is determined to expand her business. She hopes for a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and VCDs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards and VCDs to sell

loans.name: Hannah Ringa

texts.en: Hannah Ringa W. owns the Pakim Salon where she offers the services of blow drying, plaiting, wash and set, twisting, and retach and palm (African hair treatments) for friends and families. She has two employees. Her business challenges are price inflation of hair products and strong competition within her village. She is using her loan of 30,000 shillings to buy more hair products such as Venus and Nice & Lovely.  She ultimately wants to expand her business and have training schools in towns like Thika and Nairobi. She is married with one child, age 2. Hannah describes herself as hardworking, honest, respectful, intelligent and responsible.

loans.use: To buy more hair products to display in cases

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia owns a stall selling charcoal. She doesn’t pay for transport costs to and from her suppliers because she buys from the same place she works, on the outskirts of Kampala. On average, she serves 20 customers a day. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season because, when it rains, very few customers come for charcoal.

Sofia is a 35-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 2 and 10 years and she takes care of additional family members. All her children go to school. She owns a three-room house where she lives with four people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

Sofia has been in her business for ten years and with MCDT for seven years, now on her 17th loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She aspires to see her business grow stronger and to start selling only wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Damaris Njeri

texts.en:
Damaris Njeri is a 35-year-old married woman with six children. She is a dairy farmer and also a tailor. She has been selling milk for about five years with a profit of approximately 13,500 Kenyan shillings. She has never borrowed from another MFI.

Damaris does her business in Kabete center, where most of her customers are. She intends to buy more cows in order to operate a dairy milk business to increase her profit margin and improve her living standards.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buy an extra cow for her dairy milk supply business

loans.name: Pauline Wangechi

texts.en:
Pauline K. runs the Starette Junior Kindergarten in Rongai village and offers preschool and baby care for children between 1 and 6 years old. She has one employee and the school is located in a residential area, which is convenient for the working families she serves. She has had this kindergarten for two years and previously worked at Acacia Park School and the Faith Love School. 

Her challenges are late payments from parents and competition from other programs. She plans to use the proceeds from her 20,000 Kenyan shillings loan to rent a larger space and create play facilities for the children. 

Pauline sees herself as polite, patient and humble. She is married to a building designer and has five children ranging in age from 4 to 18 years old. She would like to grow her school from a preschool to a full secondary school. She is also interested in working on mothers' and children's issues for a human-rights organization. Pauline's hopes for her family are to own a permanent house and to have her children schooled to a full education.

loans.use: To rent a larger space and create playing facilities for the students

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel K. sells cereals and water in a remote but rapidly developing area (the photo shows her water transport system). She has one employee. Her customers for cereals are local families and, for water, it is foremen from local construction sites. She has been in the cereals business for three years and just recently expanded to offer water. Rachel will use the proceeds of her 20,000 shilling loan to purchase more maize, beans, rice, etc. She is married and has a 9-year-old boy and a 4-year-old girl. Hardworking, honest, obedient and disciplined – Rachel's longterm goal is to become a large wholesaler of cereals and a wealthy woman.

loans.use: To increase the stock of maize, beans, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase and resale of school supplies

loans.name: Emilienne

texts.fr: D. Emilienne est née en 1984 à Azowlissè, village situé aux environs de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Emilienne réside depuis huit ans à Takon Aïdjèdo à Porto-Novo et est mariée à ZANMENOU Marcellin, un menuisier. Emilienne est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés et vit avec ses enfants et son conjoint. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par les deux conjoints. Emilienne mène depuis cinq ans comme activité, la vente de bouillie (faite à base de maïs) accompagnée d'arachide. Emilienne s'approvisionne à Takon, à proximité de Porto-Novo et vend sa marchandise de façon ambulante. Emilienne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'augmenter la quantité de bouillie préparée par jour pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Emilienne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Emilienne is born in 1984 in Azowlisse, a village located around Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Emelienne has been living in Takon Aidjedo in Porto-Novo for eight years. She is married to ZANMENOU Marcellin, a carpenter. Emelienne is the mother of two children, all in school and she lives with her children and husband.The couple supports each other with the family expenses.Emelienne has been in this business of selling porridge( made of corn) with peanuts for five years. She gets her supplies at Takon near Porto-Novo and sells her products from door to door. Emelienne is an old customer of ALIDe having obtained two loans from ALIDe and repaid correctly. In view of expanding her working capital and increasing the quantity of porridge made daily to better satisfy her clientele, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn, sugar and coco

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La socia Francisca; pertenece al banco comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”; ubicados en el distrito de Andahuaylillas a 5 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene  30 años de edad, ella es natural de Catca, pero vive varios años en el distrito de Andahuaylillas, la socia convive con su novio, el vende todo tipo de plásticos, tiene 2 hijos y aún no se casan por que se requiere mucho dinero para efectuar la boda y aún ellos no salen de sus gastos cotidianos; ella tiene un terreno en el cual cultiva papa, y nuestra socia aprovecha este producto para vender moraya (papa deshidratada)  también vende pasto y vende también gallinas. Nuestra socia tiene este negocio formalmente desde el año 2002 y ella requiere el préstamo para comprar semillas y gallinas y otros animales menores para incrementar sus ventas y aumentar su variedad de comercio.

La socia agradece y valora el crédito así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Francisca belongs to the Las Triunfadoras Communal Bank, which is located in the Andahuaylillas district five minutes from the city of Cusco. She is 30, and she is from Catca. However, she has lived in the Andahuaylillas district for several years. She lives with her fiancé. He sells all types of plastics. She has two children. They have not yet married because it requires a lot of money to have a wedding, and they are still working on paying their daily expenses. She has a piece of land where she grows potatoes. She uses this opportunity to sell “moraya” (dehydrated potato). She also sells grass from the pastures and chickens. She has formally had this business since 2002. She needs a loan to buy seeds, chickens, and other small animals to increase her sales and expand the variety of her business. She is grateful for and values the loan. She promises to make her payments on the established time line.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and chickens

loans.name: Vicentina

texts.es:
La socia Vicentina; pertenece al banco comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”; UBICADOS EN EL DISTRITO DE Andahuaylillas a 5 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 35 años de edad, ella es natural del distrito de Quiquijana, es soltera nuestra socia alterna sus actividades con el comercio minorista, ella vende comidas en el paradero de Andahuaylillas, prepara deliciosos potajes y comidas rápidas para llevar, ella también cría cuyes para engordarlos con lo que resta de sus insumos y pasto y así venderlos sea al por mayor o en platos elaborados a base de cuy. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar animalitos de corral, hacerles su jaula y comprar insumos para la elaboración de más variedad de platos.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
She is 35, single, and she is from the Quiquijana district. She alternates her small business activities. She sells food in the Andahuaylillas station. She makes delicious soups and fast food to go. She also raises guinea pigs to fatten with the leftover ingredients and grass. This way she can sell them wholesale or use them to make dishes with guinea pigs as the main ingredient. She is asking for a loan to buy small farm animals, make their cages, and buy supplies to make a greater variety of dishes. She is grateful for and values the loan given through this means. She promises to make the payments on her debts in the established timeframe.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy small farm animals

loans.name: Florentina Matilde

texts.es:
La socia Florentina; pertenece al banco comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”; UBICADOS EN EL DISTRITO DE Andahuaylillas a 5 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 27 años de edad, ella es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos, la socia se dedica al comercio minorista; ella vende pollipapas y salchipapas (papas fritas con pollo frito o con salchichas fritas, a esto le acompaña, salsas diversas y algunas veces un poco de spaghetti) desde hace 2 años; nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para implementar su carreta de freidora y así mismo poder comprar los accesorios indispensables, así como los platos, los tenedores, las bebidas para acompañar este plato.

Nuestra socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
The member Florentina belongs to the Las Triunfadoras Community Bank, located in the Andahuaylillas District, 5 minutes from the city of Cusco.

Florentina is 27 years old, living with someone and has 2 children. For 2 years, she has been involved in retail sales of fried potatoes and fried chicken, or fried sausages, with diverse sauces and, sometimes, some spaghetti.

Florentina wishes to better better equip her frying cart by buying indispensable accessories, such as plates and forks, and drinks to accompany these dishes.

She appreciates and values the loan and is committed to comply with the repayment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BETTER EQUIP HER FRYING CART.

loans.name: Margaret Wangui

texts.en: Margaret Wangui M. owns the Magy Boutique shop where she sells skirts, shoes and bags to ladies. She has one employee. The store's location is a busy site in the market. Her business challenges are lack of funds and the need for a bigger space. She is using her loan of 20,000 shillings to buy more clothes and bags to take advantage of the December holiday shopping. She wants to be a wholesaler in the future. Margaret is married with three children and describes herself as patient, friendly and good with customers.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and bags

loans.name: Margaret Muthoni

texts.en:
Margaret Muthoni N. owns the Jomusa Shop where she sells cakes, soft drinks, eggs, milk, yogurt and handkerchiefs. Her business challenge is lack of funds which prevents her from adding a greater variety of products. She is using her loan of 20,000 shillings to buy additional cakes, crates of sodas and milk. 

Margaret is married with five children ranging in age from 2 to 11 years. Her goal for her business is to become a wholesaler. She also wants to open a hardware store with her husband, who already works in that business. She describes herself as jovial and friendly, and she has good personal relations with other people. Margaret dreams of buying land and building a house for her family so she no longer has to pay rent.

loans.use: To buy additional cakes, crates of sodas and milk

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
La socia Alejandrina; pertenece al banco comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”; UBICADOS EN EL DISTRITO DE Andahuaylillas a 5 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 47 años de edad, ella es natural de la ciudad de Puno, la socia es madre soltera, ella tiene 6 hijos, los cuales a la actualidad son independientes; ella alterna sus diversas actividades con el comercio minorista, nuestra socia vende productos secos, como granos de maíz, habas secas, frijoles secos, lentejas, porotos, pallares, entre mas variedades andinas.  

Nuestra socia agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus deudas e el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Alejandrina is a member of the Las Triunfadoras (Victorious Women) communal bank located in the district of Andahuaylillas, 5 minutes from the city of Cusco. Our member is 47 years old. She is a native of the city of Puno. The member is a single mother. She has six children who are currently independent.

Her diverse activities include a retail business. She sells dried products such as grains of corn, dried beans, lentils, string beans, and a variety of Andean beans including porotos and pallares, among others.

Our member is thankful for and values the loan and promises to make payments on her debt through the established installments.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dried grains and beans

loans.name: Susan Njoki

texts.en:
Susan Njoki N. has been running her own business, Makena Special, for two years selling used clothing. She specializes in children's clothes and ladies trousers and shoes. Her clientele is primarily women. Located in a residential area, her stall is very busy, yet she does face challenges in the form of competition and lack of capital. Susan is using the proceeds of her 20,000 shilling loan to increase her offering of ladies clothes and expand into handbags. 

Susan is married to a salesman and has two children: Doreen, age 7, and Teddy, age 3. She describes herself as having strong customer skills and she aspires to expand her offerings into new clothes and, ultimately, into a wholesale operation. Susan's life goals are to own her house and for her children to reach a higher level of education than she was able to achieve.

loans.use: To increase her stock of ladies clothes and handbags

loans.name: Real Progreso 4 Group

texts.en:
Carlos makes and sells boots to people in his community and surrounding communities. He lives with his mother and supports her financially. He plans to use the money to buy supplies to make boots. Carlos's business has grown with the help of Esperanza loans and he hopes to continue to increase his sales with this loan. His quality of life has improved since he started his business. His success in business has enabled him to buy medicine and food.

Carlos is the group coordinator for Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Real Progreso (Real Progress). His story is representative of the others in his group and more generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients. Santos and his group live in Agua Blanca, a rural community in the El Seybo province of the Dominican Republic. The community is largely made up of Haitian immigrants. Carlos can speak, read and write in Spanish, but several others in the group (and many more in the community) are illiterate. Agua Blanca is a very poor community that has unreliable (at best) access to electricity and running water.

Carlos has proven to be an excellent Esperanza client and this loan will be his sixth. Carlos would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Supplies to make boots

loans.name: Timotea

texts.es:
La socia Timotea; pertenece al banco comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”; UBICADOS EN EL DISTRITO DE Andahuaylillas a 5 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 29 años de edad la socia vive con su novio y el es agricultor, ellos tienes 4 hijos, nuestra socia alterna sus actividades con el comercio minorista, ella vende comidas en el distrito de Urcos, ella elabora sus diferentes platos de comidas rápidas y los lleva hasta el distrito de Urcos que esta situado de Andahuaylillas a Urcos a unos 20 minutos, ella se instala allá en el paradero porque de este punto salen diferentes carros, buses y empresas terrestres a Puno, Arequipa, la selva de Perú, y todos paran aquí obligadamente, lo que a ella le permite vender sus platos. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder comprar o alquilar un puesto de venta aquí en Urcos y así no tener que llevar todos los días sus ollas y sillas hasta Urcos.

Nuestra socia se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido y agradece infinitamente esta ayuda.
texts.en:
Timotea belongs to the Las Triunfadoras Communal Bank, which is located in the Andahuaylillas district five minutes from the city of Cusco. She is 29, and she lives with her fiancé who is a farmer. They have four children. She alternates her small business activities. She sells food in the Urcos district. She makes different fast food dishes. She takes them to the Urcos district, which is located 20 minutes from Andahuaylillas. She sets up at the station there because it is the point where different cars, buses, and trains depart for Puno, Arequipa, and the Peruvian jungle. They all must stop there, which allows her to sell her dishes. She is asking for a loan to be able to buy or rent a place to sell here in Urcos. That way she will not have to take her pots and chairs with her to Urcos everyday.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy or rent a place to sell so that she can leave her cooking utensils there

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: K. Ablavi est née en 1974 à Abatamè au Togo, État voisin du Bénin. Ablavi vit à Takon  Aïdjèdo à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, il y a une vingtaine d’année. Mariée à DJISSOUKPE Marcellin un cultivateur, Ablavi est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Ablavi n’a jamais été à l’école ; elle a commencé il y a quinze ans, la préparation de sodabi (boisson alcoolisée locale) qu’elle vend à son domicile. Ablavi vend également de l’huile de palme à Ouando à Porto-Novo. Ablavi s’approvisionne dans les localités environnantes et au marché Ouando. Ablavi est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé. Ablavi a bien remboursé les deux crédits précédents qu’elle a obtenus. C’est pour renforcer son activité et augmenter sa production journalière, afin de vendre davantage ses produits que Ablavi sollicite ce troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Ablavi K. was born in 1974 in Abatamè in Togo, a neighboring country of Benin. She has been living for 20 years in Takon Aïdjèdo in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is the wife of Marcellin Djissoukpe, a farmer, and the mother of four children who all attend school. The parents provide together for their family.

Ablavi never went to school. 15 years ago she began to produce sodabi, a local alcoholic drink, which she sells from her home. She sells also palm oil in Ouando in Porto-Novo. She gets her supplies in the nearby villages and at Ouando market. This is her third loan from Alidé. She repaid her previous two loans on schedule. Ablavi applies for this loan to boost her business and increase her daily production, so that she can sell more.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm oil and produce sodabi

loans.name: Hipolita

texts.es:
La socia Hipolita; pertenece al banco comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”; UBICADOS EN EL DISTRITO DE Andahuaylillas a 5 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 34 años de edad la socia vive con su novio y tienes 4 hijos, nuestra socia alterna sus actividades con el comercio minorista, ella vende ponches calientes de todo tipo, también inicio la venta de helados caseros, nuestra socia esta incrementando poco a poco su negocio y expandiéndolo; la socia requiere el préstamo para comprar una heladera.

Nuestra socia se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido y agradece infinitamente esta ayuda.
texts.en:
Hipolita belongs to the Las Triunfadoras Communal Bank, which is located in the Andahuaylillas district five minutes from the city of Cusco. She is 34, and she lives with her fiancé. They have four children. She alternates her small business activities. She sells warm punches of all kinds. She also started selling homemade ice cream. She is increasing her business little by little and expanding it. She needs a loan to buy a refrigerator. She promises to make all of her payments on the established timeframe. She is infinitely grateful for this help.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The client is 36 years old, married and has one child. The client has been selling electronics for a couple of years in addition to working as a school teacher. The client started this business in order to supplement his income.  With this loan the client is expecting to grow his business so that in the future he can hire an assistant to help around the shop.

loans.use: repairing and purchasing mobile phones and computers

loans.name: Laurence

texts.fr: H. Laurence est née en 1979 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est depuis douze ans que Laurence vit à Katagon Agaégon à proximité de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Laurence est mariée à GNONLONFOUN Akim et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Laurence a deux autres enfants à sa charge, en plus de ses deux enfants. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par le  couple. Laurence n’a jamais été à l’école ; et il y a douze ans déjà que Laurence mène comme activité, la préparation de l’huile de palme et de la boisson alcoolisée locale communément appelée Sodabi. Laurence fait ses emplettes au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo et à Cotonou. C’est à son domicile et au marché Ouando qu’elle vend ses produits. Laurence a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Afin d’augmenter sa production pour mieux servir sa clientèle, Laurence sollicite un troisième crédit. Laurence ambitionne plus tard acquérir sa propre parcelle.
texts.en:
Laurence H. was born in 1979 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been living for twelve years in Katagon Agaégon, near Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is the wife of Akim Gnonlonfoun and the mother of two children who both attend school. Laurence cares for two other children, in addition to her own two children. The parents provide together for their family.

Laurence never went to school. Twelve years ago she began to produce palm oil and sodabi, a local alcoholic drink. Laurence gets her supplies at Ouando market in Porto-Novo and in Cotonou. She sells her products at home and at Ouando market. She received already two loans from Alidé, which she repaid on schedule. Laurence applies for her third loan to increase her production and better serve her customers. Her ambition is to buy later her own plot of land.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Top buy sugar and palm nuts

loans.name: Justine

texts.fr: T. Justine est née en 1981 à Gbagla au Bénin. Justine vit depuis douze ans à Katagon Agaégon à proximité de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Justine est mariée à ADANDE Pascal un cultivateur et est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Les deux conjoints supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Justine n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour aider son conjoint dans les charges de la famille, Justine s’est mise depuis dix ans déjà, à vendre du maïs et des plats à Azowlissè et à Takon, deux villages situés à proximité de Porto-Novo. C’est à Kétou, au Sud du Bénin et à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Justine s’approvisionne. Justine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursé. Pour agrandir davantage son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de la clientèle, Justine sollicite à nouveau un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Justine ambitionne accroître son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Justine T. was born in 1981 in Gbagla in Benin. She has been living for twelve years in Katagon Agaégon, near Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is the wife of Pascal Adande, a farmer, and the mother of four children who all attend school. The parents provide together for their family.

Justine never went to school. To help her husband to provide for the family, Justine began ten years ago to sell corn and dishes in Azowlissè and Takon, two villages close to Porto-Novo. Justine gets her supplies in Kétou in southern Benin and in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a known Alidé customer who received already two loans, which she repaid on schedule. Justine came to Alidé and applied for her third loan to boost her business and better meet the demand of her customers. Her ambition is to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and dishes

loans.name: Amara

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Amara Traoré est âgée de 38 ans, marié et père d’un enfant. Il vit  dans une famille nucléaire avec sa femme et son unique enfant au quartier ATTBOUGOU de la ville Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant  abandonné l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour des raisons familiales (parents extrêmement pauvres). Il commença alors les activités génératrices de revenus en devenant l’agent marketing d’un commerçant de la place. Après plusieurs années passées auprès de ce dernier, il décide d’évoluer seul en optant pour le commerce d’habits, qu’il mène depuis maintenant 2 ans.  Il jouit d’une grande réputation et notoriété grâce à son sens des affaires et surtout à son enthousiasme. 
Dans l’intention  d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, il fait recours au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui,  il est à son  premier  prêt individuel. 
Il compte utiliser ce montant pour acheter, 15 pièces de pagnes wax de qualités et modèles différents. Il s’approvisionne sur place auprès des grossistes du grand marché de Ségou. Monsieur  Amara Traoré  vend ses pagnes, en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 40 000FCFA par mois. Le bénéfice réalisé lui permettra de prendre en charge les dépenses familiales (nourritures, habillements et soins médicaux) et rembourser les intérêts du prêt. 
Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique de vente de pagnes et de bazins à Ségou.
texts.en:
Mr. Amara Traore is 38 years old, married and the father of a child. He lives in a nucleus family with his wife and only child in the ATTBOUGOU neighborhood of Segou town( fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having abandoned school in the ninth basic year (Malian education system) owing to family reasons( parents very poor), he began an income generating business by becoming a marketing agent of a shopkeeper in the area. After several years spent besides this shopkeeper, he decided to develop alone, opting for the clothing business which he operates 2 years ago. He has great name and reputation thanks to his sense of business and above all, his enthusiasm. With the intention to expand his wrking capital in order to make more profits, he turns toward the micro-finance institution Siro Yiriwaso for his first individual loan. He intends to use this amount to buy 15 pieces of different styles of quality wax cloth. He gets his supplies right from wholesalers from the big market of Segou. Mr. Amara Traore sells these clothes retail for cash and for credit to a clientele principally composed of women. He expects to make a monthly profit of 40,000FCFA. The profit will enable him to take care of family expenses( food, clothes, medical care) and to repay the interest of the loan. His ambition is to open a fabric and bazin store in Segou.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wax cloth (fabrics)

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The client is 21 years old and unmarried. He makes traditional Iraqi sweets. He has been engaged in this activity for the last four years. He has two assistants helping him around the shop. With this loan he hopes to buy more ingredients for making sweets and hire another assistant. The client has a good reputation in the city and has lots of customers.

loans.use: purchasing ingredients: nuts, flour, oil and seeds

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe  Benkadi sont tous des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne 42 ans et 2 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers avec l’achat et  vente de bois de chauffe,  de céréales, d’oranges, de friperie etc.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur  quatrième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts  précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 2 chargements de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 5 sacs de 100 kg de céréales, 2 colis de friperie et 2 chargements de charrettes en oranges. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et les villages avoisinants auprès des producteurs. Elles vendent dans les différents marchés, dans les autres quartiers de la ville de Sikasso et à domicile au comptant, souvent à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Benkadi are all married, they are on average 42 years old and have on average two children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhood of the town of Sikasso, the third administrative region of the republic of Mali.

This group of women trades various items such as firewood, cereals, oranges, secondhand clothing etc… They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwasso in order to meet the needs of their customers. This is their fourth group loan. All the previous loans have been fully reimbursed.

With their new loan, they plan on buying 2 small truck loads of firewood, 5 bags of 100 kg of cereals, 2 bales of secondhand clothing and 2 cart loads of oranges.

They buy their goods from the market in Sikasso town and from local farmers in the neighboring villages. They sell in different markets, in other neighborhoods of Sikasso and from their homes. They sell for cash, often on credit, to customers made up of men and women.

They are each planning to make an average monthly profit of 18,500 CFA (about USD 41.50) of which one part will be used for savings and to meet the needs of the families, and the other part will be reinvested in the businesses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 1 And 3 Group

texts.en:
Valentina is the group coordinator for Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Mujeres Unidas (United Women). Her story is representative of the others in her group and more generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients. Valentina and her five children live in Hato Mayor, a rural area in the Dominican Republic. 

Valentina is an excellent Esperanza client and has successfully repaid seven loans. With this loan, her eighth, she plans to buy fruit to sell in her community. Specifically, she will purchase oranges, plantains and bananas. 

Using the proceeds from her business, Valentina has been able to purchase clothes and food for her children. She has also repaired some parts of her house. Her dream for the future is to continue to educate her children and make improvements to her house. Valentina thanks you for your support in helping her achieve her goals!

loans.use: Oranges, plantains, bananas and other fruits

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont tous des  femmes mariées  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 3 enfants, et  vivant la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye,  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait l’achat et la vente de condiments alimentaires, de fruits et légumes, de bois de chauffe, de riz et de la restauration. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur quatrième collaboration avec l’institution  et tous les trois précédents prêts ont se sont  bien dénoués. 
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1sac de 100kg de riz, 4 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 2 chargements de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 1 sac de 100kg de graines d’arachide (pour  faire de la pâte d’arachide pour la restauration) et 10 paniers de fruits. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants. Elles effectuent leurs ventes à domicile, de façon fixe dans les marchés et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante. Elles vendent au comptant, souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Kotognogontala group are all married women who are on average 32 years old with 3 children, and live mainly in monogamous households in Hamdallaye, one of the districts in the town of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. This group of women are engaged in buying and selling food condiments, fruits and vegetables, firewood, and rice, and in preparing meals for sale. In order to satisfy the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their fourth collaboration with the institution, and all three of their previous loans were repaid properly. With their new loan, they intend to buy one 100-kg bag of rice, 4 packets of food condiments, 2 van-loads of firewood, one 100-kg bag of peanuts (to make peanut paste for meal preparation), and 10 baskets of fruit. They obtain their supplies at the grand market in the town of Sikasso and in the neighbouring villages. They sell their goods at home, at stands in the markets, and door-to-door in various districts. They sell in cash and often on credit to a clientele composed of men and women. They foresee realizing an average monthly profit of 18,500 FCFA each, of which one portion will be used as savings and to provide for their families, and the rest invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell various items

loans.name: Soumaïla

texts.fr: A. Soumaïla est né en 1954 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Soumaïla vit depuis vingt cinq ans à Zounkpa à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Soumaïla est marié à GANHOUINGNON Agnès, une revendeuse d’engrais. Le couple a huit enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. En plus de ces enfants, Soumaïla a également un enfant à charge. Soumaïla et Agnès supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Soumaïla exerce depuis une vingtaine d’année le métier de jardinier. En plus de cela, Soumaïla vend des produits phytosanitaires à son domicile.  Soumaïla s’approvisionne à Akouèto au Bénin. Soumaïla est à son deuxième crédit à ALIDé. Le premier crédit a été bien remboursé. Pour étendre son activité, afin de mieux répondre aux attentes de ses clients et de sa famille, Soumaïla sollicite ce deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Soumaïla A. was born in 1954 in Ouidah, a historic city in Benin. He has been living for 25 years in Zounkpa in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. He is married to Agnès Ganhouingnon, a merchant of fertilizer. The parents have eight children who all attend school. In addition, Soumaïla cares for another child. Soumaïla and Agnès provide together for their family.

Soumaïla has been a gardener for 20 years. He also sells plant-care products from his home. He gets his supplies in Akouèto in Benin. This is Soumaïla’s second loan with Alidé. His first loan was repaid on schedule. To boost his business, better meet the demand of his customers and provide for his family, Soumaïla came to Alidé and applied for his second loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a powered pump

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont tous des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles monogames à Mancourani II, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts antérieurs ont été remboursés sans aucune difficulté. 
Elles font de la vente de condiments alimentaires, de pagnes wax et de chaussures. 
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 20 cartons de condiments alimentaires, 50 paires de chaussures  et  5 pièces de pagnes wax.  
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et vendent à Sikasso ville: à domicile, dans les marchés et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante. Elles vendent au comptant, souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles espèrent avoir des prêts plus importants pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  faire de l’épargne pour préparer l’avenir des enfants.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Sabougnouma are all married women who average 40 years of age and 3 children each.  They live for the most part in monogamous families in Mancourani II, a district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of Mali).  They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers and are now on their sixth solidarity loan.  All the previous loans have been repaid without any difficulties at all. The group members sell condiments, shoes, and Wax  pagnes (colorful West African cloth).  With their new loan, they intend to buy 20 boxes of condiments, 50 pairs of shoes, and 5 bolts of Wax pagnes.  The merchandise is gotten at the big market of Sikasso City and is sold in Sikasso, in homes, at the marketplaces, and door-to-door in the districts.  Sales are made in cash and often on credit to customers composed of men and women.  The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 19,500 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be put into savings for family needs.  And the other portion will be re-invested into the businesses.  The women hope to have larger loans to satisfy their customers further and to save more money to provide a future for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Soutoura. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Soutoura, toutes mariées, ont une moyenne d’âge de 36ans, 4 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur neuvième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’orange, de sucre, de lait, d’oignon et poissons fumé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 20 paniers d’orange,  50 kg de sucre,  50 kg de lait, 5 sacs d’oignon et 8 cartons de poisson fumé, au grand marché de Sikasso ville et les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont revendues en détail, dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, la plupart au comptant. 
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée rembourser le prêt et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Soutoura ambitionnent augmenter le montant de leurs prêts  pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Soutoura are all married and average 36 years of age and 4 children.  The women live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of Mali). These group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers and are now on their ninth solidarity loan.  All the past loans have been repaid.  They operate diverse businesses, including selling oranges, sugar, milk, onions, and smoked fish.  With this new loan, they intend to buy 20 baskets of oranges, 50 kg of sugar, 50 kg of milk, 5 sacks of onions, and 8 boxes of smoked fish.  These goods are gotten at the Sikasso City market and neighboring towns and are sold retail at different markets of Sikasso and in the different districts.  The customers are composed of men and women, most of whom pay in cash.  The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 11,500 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be used to repay the loan, and the other portion will be invested in the businesses.  The women have the ambition of obtaining larger  loans in order to satisfy their customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock palm oil

loans.name: Esperanza Y Desarrollo 3 Group

texts.en:
Bethania is a 27-year-old borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Confianza y Desarrollo 3 (Confidence and Development), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Bethania lives in Batey La Plaza, a small community north of San Pedro. A batey is a community built by sugar companies for their workers, and they are synonymous with poverty. La Plaza lacks running water, any kind of reliable electricity, and is a great distance from the nearest medical facility. In addition, Bethania lives in a crowded home made of only thin wood panels. She has three children (6, 5, and 4 years old) and lives with her mother and brother.

This is Bethania’s first loan with Esperanza International. Other borrowers in her community expressed their satisfaction with Esperanza, and Bethania decided a new loan would be great for her business. Bethania makes and sells underwear for the women and children in her community. She expects that the loan will help her business expand greatly. Along with an expanding business, Bethania hopes her profits will increase so she can send all of her children through school and possibly move into her own home someday. Thank you for lending to Bethania and the Confianza y Desarrollo 3 group!

loans.use: Cloth and supplies

loans.name: Peuya

texts.fr:
C'est le premier crédit pour Madame Peuya M., une vendeuse de cosmétiques a Camberene, une banlieue de Dakar.  Elle voudrait augmenter son fond de roulement pour mieux soutenir sa famille.  Aujourd'hui elle a une revenu de 25.000 frs par mois mais elle envisage une augmentation a 35.000 frs après le prêt.

Madame M. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires..  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
This is the first loan for Mrs Peuya M. who sells cosmetics in Cambere, a suburb of Dakar. She would like to increase her working capital to better provide for her family. Currently her monthly income amounts to 25,000 CFA francs (US$57), but she expects it to rise to 35,000 CFA francs (US$80) when she has got the loan.

Mrs M. is a beneficiary of the Protocol between Kiva Partner U-IMCEC and the Development Program for Children and Families "Seydina Issa Laye". This Program seeks to reduce poverty within the community and especially to protect children from destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these families can benefit from loans with more flexible terms than ordinary loans. Since the start of this Protocol in December 2008, 120 parents have received loans in amounts varying from 50,000 to 150,000 CFA francs (US$114-343).

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de  huit femmes (4 veuves et 4 mariées) vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 58 ans, 5 enfants  et habitant  le quartier Djaka (Kirango) de Markala (4ème Région administrative du Mali : Ségou). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et de voisinage et exercent comme activité génératrice de revenus l’achat vente et la transformation de poissons. Actuellement elles se sont organisées en  coopérative de transformatrices de poisson initiée par l’A.N.P.E. (Agence Nationale Pour L’Emploi). Elles ont reçus  des  formations portant sur les différentes méthodes de transformation et de conservation des poissons dans les mesures d’hygiène suivant les normes du  BIT (Bureau International du Travail). Elles bénéficièrent alors de deux fours modernes et des séchoirs. 
Après 4 prêts solidaires auprès de Soro Yiriwaso, tous bien remboursés, elles sont à leur 5ème prêt de groupe. 
Ce prêt leur permettra d’acheter, 80 paniers de poissons et 200 barres de glace. Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger, elles les trient, une bonne partie de ce poisson est séchée ou fumée. Le poisson frais se vend sur place, à Ségou ville (marché château), à Bamako,  Koutiala et Sikasso. Le poisson séché est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango et à Ségou. Une  partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue où elles gagnent plus d’argent. Le poisson fumé est essentiellement vendu à Ségou. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant, en détail et à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 81.300 FCFA qui servira à augmenter le volume de leurs activités, à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux (habillements, savon, pétrole) et à participer aux évènements sociaux (baptême, mariage et décès). 
Elles ont pour ambition une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Benkadi is an association of eight women (4 widowed and 4 married) who live in large traditional families.  The women average 58 years of age and 5 children each. And they live in the Djaka district (Kirango) of Markala (4th administrative region of Mali: Ségou).  They know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, and community.  Their income-generating work involves the buying and selling of fish and the processing of it.  Currently, the women are organized into a cooperative of fish processors initiated by A.N.P.E. (a national jobs agency).  They've received training on the different methods for processing and preserving fish, insofar as hygienic standards per the BIT (international bureau of work).  The women were then the recipients of two modern ovens and some dryers.  After four solidarity loans with Soro Yiriwaso, all repaid, the women are now on their fifth group loan  This loan will enable them to purchase 80 baskets of fish and 200 bars of ice.  Supplies of fresh fish are gotten locally on the banks of the Niger River.  The fish are sorted, and much of it is dried or smoked.  The fresh fish is sold locally in Segou City (Château Market), Bamako, Koutiala, and Sikasso.  The dried fish is most of all sold in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, and Segou.  A portion is kept until the waters recede, when the women earn more money.  The smoked fish is sold essentially in Segou.  Sales are made generally in cash at the retail level and on credit.  The customers are composed of women and men.  The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 81,300 francs CFA that will be used to increase their business volume, to satisfy sundry family needs (clothing, soap, fuel), and to assist with social events (baptisms, marriages, and funerals).  Their ambition is to have a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Djiman Honorine

texts.fr: D. Djiman Honorine est née en 1973 à Abidjan en Côte d'Ivoire. Djiman Honorine vit depuis son enfance à Porto-Novo, Capitale administrative du Bénin. Djiman Honorine est mariée à AGONMA Joachin, un menuisier. Le couple n'a pas encore d'enfant. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par les deux conjoints. Djiman Honorine a arrêté les classes depuis le cours primaire et s'est mise à vendre des chaussures, des tissus et des glacières il y a de cela dix ans. Djiman Honorine s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin et vient vendre ses produits en face de l'Eglise Sainte Anne d'Agbokou à Porto-Novo. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits et qui ont été bien remboursés. Afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Djiman Honorine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Djiman Honorine is born in 1973 in Abidjan in Cote d'Ivoire.Djiman Honorine has been living since childhood in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is married to AGONMA Joachin, a carpenter. The couple has no children yet. The couple support each other with family expenses.Djiman stopped attending classes since primary school and began to sell shoes, fabrics and ice chests for ten years now.Djiman Honorine gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin and comes to sell her goods in front of St. Anne church of Agbokou in Porto-Novo. She is an old customer of ALIDe who has already benefitted from two loans which have been repaid correctly. In order to expand her working capital and better satisfy her clientele, Djiman Honorine is requesting a third loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pieces of fabric and pairs of shoes

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Composé de huit femmes (7 mariées et une veuve) vivant dans des ménages polygames, les membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Traoré Ton ont en moyenne 50 ans, 3 enfants  et habitent  le quartier Djaka (Kirango) de Markala (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali : Ségou). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens d’amitié, de groupe d’âge et professionnels. Elles excellent dans l’achat vente et la transformation de poisson. 
Le groupe  Benkadi est à son 5ème prêt solidaire,  après avoir bien remboursés les quatre précédents.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt  pour acheter, 72 paniers et 100 barres  de glace. Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger, qu’elles  trient, une bonne partie de ce poisson est séché  sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos ». Le poisson frais se vend sur place à Kirango, à Diamarabougou Markala, à Ségou ville (marché château) et à Bamako.  Le poisson séché est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin et à foire hebdomadaire de Ségou dont une partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue où elles gagnent plus d’argent. Quant au poisson fumé il est essentiellement vendu à Ségou.
 Les ventes se font généralement au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent  réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 62.000 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux  (complément de prix de condiments, habillements, savon, pétrole) et à participer aux évènements sociaux (baptême, mariage et décès). 
Elles ambitionnent avoir une concession qui leur soit propre afin de préparer l’avenir des enfants.
texts.en:
The group is made up of eight women (7 are married and one is a widow). The live in multifamily households. The members of the group Benkadi of the Traore Ton Association have an average age of 50 and have 3 children each. They live in the the Djaka (Kirango) district of Markala, the 4th administrative region of the Republic Mali.

They all know each other through acquaintances, from their common age group, and through business links. They are experts in the business of buying and selling, and in fish processing.

The Benkadi group are requestin their 5th loan, after having successfully repaid the four previous loans.

They plan to use their new loan to purchase 72 trays and 100 blocks of ice. They purchase fresh fish along the Niger river, but a significant portion of the fish they buy is also dried on either gravel or straw mats named “seccos”. The fresh fish is sold in Kirango, in Diamarabougou Markala, in Segou (in the Chateau market), and in Bamako. The dried fish is mostly sold in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin, and at the weekly fair in Segou, though a portion is saved until the fall when they can earn more money. Smoked fish is mostly sold in Segou.

Sales are generally completed in cash or credit, and their clientele is made up of both men and women.

They hope to see their monthly revenues bring in 62 FCFA, which will permit them to meet their family’s needs (including the price of condiments, clothing, soaps, and petroleum) and to participate to social events (baptisms, weddings, and funerals).

Their goal is to perfect their business so that they will be able to provide a good future for their children.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fish.

loans.name: Yaye Faty

texts.fr:
Madame Yaye Faty T. vend régulièrement des tissus à Camberene, une banlieue au nord de Dakar et non loin de la mer.  Sa journée de travail commence généralement a 9h et se termine a 17h.  Avec cette crédit, elle envisage élargir son marche, diversifier ses produits et augmenter son revenu  de 50.000 frs par mois.  Elle a deux enfants et elle est mariée. 

Madame T. est une bénéficiaire du protocole entre U-IMCEC et le Programme de Développement de l'Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF) Seydina Issa Laye.  Le PDEF cherche à réduire la pauvreté au sein de la communauté et surtout à protéger les enfants issus des familles démunies.  Grâce a cette coopération, les parentes de ces derniers peuvent profiter de crédit a des conditions plus souples par rapport aux crédits ordinaires..  Depuis le démarrage du protocole en Décembre 2008, 120 parents ont reçu un financement pour des montants qui varient entre 50.000 et 150.000 frs.
texts.en:
Ms. Yaye Faty T. regularly sells cloth in Camberene, a suburb in northern Dakar and not far from the ocean. Her workday generally starts at 9:00 AM and ends at 5:00 PM. With this loan, she envisions expanding her market, diversifying her goods, and increasing her revenues of 50,000 francs a month. She has two children and is married. Ms. T. is a beneficiary of the agreement between U-IMCEC and the PDEF (program for child and family development) Seydina Issa Laye. The PDEF seeks to reduce poverty within the community and especially to protect children born of destitute families. Thanks to this cooperation, the parents of these children can take advantage of loans having more flexible terms compared to ordinary loans. Since the agreement's start in December 2008, there have been 120 parents who received financing in amounts ranging from 50,000 to 150,000 francs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: B. Bernadette est née en 1964 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Bernadette réside au quartier Zounkpa à Porto-Novo depuis une vingtaine d’année. C’est une veuve qui a à sa charge ses deux enfants tous scolarisés. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par elle seule. Bernadette a arrêté les classes au cours primaire. Il y a huit ans de cela que Bernadette prépare et vend de l’akassa à son domicile. Bernadette vend également des oignons.
